column2: purpose = Preserve Endangered Cultural Heritage and Ecosystems, Promoting Open Access

column1: The '''Arcadia Fund''' is a UK charity organisation founded by [[Lisbet Rausing]] and Professor [[Peter Baldwin (professor)
column2: Peter Baldwin]]. Established in 2001, the organisation provides grants on a worldwide basis. Its primary focus currently is preserving endangered culture, preserving endangered nature and providing open access.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column10: title=About us - preserving endangered culture and nature and promoting open access

column1: Since 2002, the fund has provided in excess of $570 million in projects around the world.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Arcadia - preserve endangered culture and nature

column1: The foundation is controlled by its three trustees ([[Lisbet Rausing]], [[Peter Baldwin (professor)
column2: Peter Baldwin]] and Dr Johannes Burger) and its team of 9 members. The fund also has an advisory board of 7 members.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Arcadia has since 2002 provided in excess of $570 million globally in Grants.<ref name=\":3\" /> The grants are divided into 5 categories: Cultural, Environmental, Open Access, Discretionary and Discontinued Themes as shown in the following table  <ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web

Arcadia's supported causes since inception in 2002 have been preserving endangered culture, preserving endangered nature and open access. Arcadia's has a selected issues criterion in which the organisation use's to choose grants. The methodology of grant choices has not changed since 2002 however, supported causes has altered slightly. Arcadia aims to provide cultural grants to universities, archives or museums that preserve cultural heritage and digitise near-extinct cultural heritage. Additionally, Arcadia provides environmental grants to organisations that preserve endangered habitats, at risk land as well as trains staff, enable research and policy development. Arcadia also aims to provide open access grants to increase access of free material such online as research papers and publications.<ref name=\":1\" />

Arcadia also supported causes such as human rights, philanthropy and education however since 2009 the support for the causes have been discontinued.<ref name=\":1\" />  The fund supported organisations around these discontinued themes that helped refugee scholars, educated disadvantaged children in Africa, and conducted women's right advocacy.<ref name=\":5\" />
The Graph shows the fund's grants per years<ref name=\":2\" /><graph>{
Arcadia awards grants to organisations preserving endangered culture, preserving nature, and promoting open access.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Grants - dynamic, sustainable and well researched programmes

column1: Arcadia's largest grant was in 2002, to the [[SOAS, University of London
column2: School of Oriental and African Studies]]— totalling £20 million (US$33,851,813) to start the [[Endangered Languages Archive
column3: Endangered Language Documentation Program (ELDP)]]. The program enables scholars to undertake documentation of disappearing languages. By 2015, the program has documented over 350 languages. The grant also funds training scholars in modern language documentation techniques. The fund   donated another US$11 million in April 2015 .<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=SOAS’ Endangered Languages Documentation Programme receives a further $11 million from Arcadia {{!}} SOAS University of London

column1: In  2004 the fund founded the Endangered Archives Program at the [[British Library]] with a $25 million grant supporting the digitisation of at risk collections around the world. By Sept 2018,  the program has supported more than 350 documentation programs in 90 countries, with over 6.5 million images and 25,000 sound tracks being preserved. The material is available freely online as part of the [[Endangered Archives Programme]].<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2019-05-28}}</ref> In 2018 the fund gave an additional  £9 million to fund the program for a further 7 years. <ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=New grant to the Endangered Archives Programme

column1: In 2013 and 2015 provide  $1 million  to the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s collaboration with the [[National Museum of Natural History
column2: Natural History Museum]]'s \"Recovering Voices Initiative,\"  a long-term project  to digitise audio recordings, manuscripts and photographs. It aims to digitise the entire collection of ethnographic sound recordings, estimated at 3,000 hours, and 35,000 pages of manuscript materials.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Arcadia Fund Gift Furthers Global Access to Endangered Languages
column7: access-date=2019-05-06}}</ref> In 2015 it  provided a $511,200 to the Smithsonian Campaign, 'The Field Book Project', to preserve field books, the  original records of scientific expeditions.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2019-05-07}}</ref>   The grant aimed to support the digitising of 2600 field books, all which will be open access.<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title=The Arcadia Fund Awards Grant to Support The Field Book Project – Biodiversity Heritage Library
column17: access-date=2019-05-07}}</ref> Currently, the project has catalogued over 9,500 field books and digitised over 4,000.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: Arcadia in 2018 gave £23 million (US$31,441,100)   to the Cambridge Conservative Initiative (CCI) for the Endangered Landscapes Programme (ELP). Arcadia in collaboration with CCI and 9 other conservation organisations aim to reserve priority landscape across Europe  to support viable populations of native species, provide room for natural ecological processes, resilience of ecosystems to short or long term changes.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Restoring Europe’s endangered landscapes for life

column1: Arcadia in 2018 gave Fauna & Flora International   $USD 27,000,000 for Halcyon Land & Sea Fund. The partnership started in 1998 where Peter Baldwin and Lisbet Rausing developed the idea in conjunction with FFI to develop the Halcyon Fund in which secures highly threatened sites to protect them under local management. As of 2018, the fund has supported 46 projects in 25 countries, protecting 55.8 million hectares of habitat.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Major grant from Arcadia will help FFI manage vital areas for conservation {{!}} Fauna & Flora International
column5: access-date=2019-05-15}}</ref> Since 2011, the fund has provided support in which has supported 34 initiatives across 18 countries.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web
column7: title=Tracking wolves and tracking progress {{!}} Fauna & Flora International
column9: access-date=2019-05-15}}</ref> Currently, Arcadia's total funding to FFI is $USD 51,550,000 million.<ref name=\":2\" /> In 2015, Arcadia ordered an independent expert review of the work it had funded through FFI, which  stated that, \"The report clearly recognises the invaluable role that Arcadia has played in helping FFI evolve into the organisation it is today, by providing long-term and flexible funding for a considerable and effective body of work.\".<ref name=\":4\" /> Its first grant in 2011 for the Halcyon Marine Programme has led to a programme in 72 sites in 17 countries withr 88 partners and 35 community-based institutions and has already resulted in threat reduction of biodiversity recovery at 10 sites.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Arcadia has provided multiple grants to Harvard University  to improve open access at the university. In 2009 it awarded  $5 million over a 5-year period.<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Harvard University Library awarded $5M grant from Arcadia Fund
column7: access-date=2019-05-29}}</ref> The grant wil  support the processing of 17th and 18th century collections in archives and underwrite conservation treatments of fragile or damaged 17th or 18th century collections. It will also help to catalogue and digitise documents on Harvard's history, and to run the Library Lab programme to improve digital services .<ref name=\":2\" /> I Arcadia provided further support to the university in 2011 with an additional $11 million grant.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: In September 2015, the fund gave $450,000 over 3 years to [[Creative Commons]]. to develop tools that complement current CC licence suite.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Creative Commons awarded $450,000 from the Arcadia Fund to support open access publishing for authors

column1: In September 2017, the fund gave $5 million to the [[Wikimedia Foundation]], the largest contribution to the foundation at the time.   <ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Matching gift grows Wikimedia Endowment by $10 million – Wikimedia Blog
column5: access-date=2019-05-04}}</ref> It gave another $3.5 million   in 2019<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=Peter Baldwin, Lisbet Rausing give an additional $3.5 million to the Wikimedia Endowment

column1: The Arcadia Fund in 2015 gave $25 million to [[Yale University]] to renovate the Yale Hall of Graduates Studies enabling the university to co-locate the dispersed humanities departments to under one roof. offering a setting for cross-disciplinary collaboration and advance research. .<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Gift to transform Hall of Graduate Studies honors David Swensen
column7: access-date=2019-05-28}}</ref> Baldwin and Rausing have asked in tribute to the service of [[David F. Swensen
column8: David Swensen]] (Who built Yale's endowment from $1.3 billion to $23.9 billion) that the building should be named after him.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Yale to name building after Swensen

column1: Arcadia gave £5 million to the illuminated River Foundation in 2017 <ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Multi-million pound donation gives Illuminated River project the green light for next year
column5: access-date=2019-05-31}}</ref>towards its program for a commissioned art installation of light to 15 of Central London's bridges along the River Thames. When the project is completed it would be the longest art commission in the world at 2.5 miles long.  ref>{{Cite web

column1: The fund before 2009 were involved in supporting  human rights,  supporting organisations to help refugee scholars, educate disadvantaged children in Africa, and conduct women's right advocacy. In 2005, it provided a $5 million grant to the Mvule Trust, to provide bursaries to young women in Uganda   to attend secondary school. The grant and trust gave 75% of scholarships to girls and by 2007 and the trust had supported the education of 1,868 children.<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web

Arcadia has provided a total of $6 million in 2005–06  to the Human Rights Watch (US)  to help their empirical research into persecution of women, and its fact gathering, press releases, advocacy and lobbying .<ref name=\":2\" /> .<ref name=\":5\" />

column3: School of Oriental and African Studies]]

column2: The Academic Programme to train linguists documenting endangered languages.
Cambridge Conservation Initiative:  Endangered Landscapes Programme
To develop and support large-scale projects seeking to create habitats that are rich in biodiversity and resilient to environmental change.
Halcyon Programmes and core institutional support
To  expand the success of both the Halcyon Land & Sea Fund and the Halcyon Marine Programme to date, increasing focus on long-term sustainability.
Institute for the Preservation of Cultural Heritage
To build a new cultural conservation and digitisation centre.
To refurbish the Hall of Graduate Studies and to support the programmatic agenda that will transform it into a central home for the humanities at Yale
To establish a  grants programme that funds projects that  digitise neglected, vulnerable or inaccessible archives relating to  pre-industrial societies.
School of Oriental  and African Studies
To continue to support the Endangered Languages Documentation Programme.
To support  Harvard College Fellows Program.
To establish the Endowed History Department Chair and History Department Chair Quasi-Endowment  Fund.
Cambridge Conservation Initiative: Endowment of Directorship
To establish an endowment fund for the Cambridge Conservation Initiative Directorship.
Supporting Open Access with Harvard Library
To improve acquisition policies and access to the library's collections.

The partnership started in 1998 where Peter Baldwin and Lisbet Rausing developed the idea in conjunction with FFI to develop the Halcyon Fund in which secures highly threatened sites to protect them under local management. As of 2018, the fund has supported 46 projects in 25 countries, protecting 55.8 million hectares of habitat.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Major grant from Arcadia will help FFI manage vital areas for conservation {{!}} Fauna & Flora International
column5: access-date=2019-05-15}}</ref> Since 2011, the fund has provided support in which has supported 34 initiatives across 18 countries.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web
column7: title=Tracking wolves and tracking progress {{!}} Fauna & Flora International
column9: access-date=2019-05-15}}</ref> Currently, Arcadia's total funding to FFI is $USD 51,550,000 million.<ref name=\":2\" /> In 2015, Arcadia ordered an independent expert review of the work it had funded through FFI, which  stated that, \"The report clearly recognises the invaluable role that Arcadia has played in helping FFI evolve into the organisation it is today, by providing long-term and flexible funding for a considerable and effective body of work.\".<ref name=\":4\" /> Its first grant in 2011 for the Halcyon Marine Programme has led to a programme in 72 sites in 17 countries withr 88 partners and 35 community-based institutions and has already resulted in threat reduction of biodiversity recovery at 10 sites.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Arcadia has provided multiple grants to Harvard University  to improve open access at the university. In 2009 it awarded  $5 million over a 5-year period.<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Harvard University Library awarded $5M grant from Arcadia Fund
column7: access-date=2019-05-29}}</ref> The grant wil  support the processing of 17th and 18th century collections in archives and underwrite conservation treatments of fragile or damaged 17th or 18th century collections. It will also help to catalogue and digitise documents on Harvard's history, and to run the Library Lab programme to improve digital services .<ref name=\":2\" /> I Arcadia provided further support to the university in 2011 with an additional $11 million grant.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: In September 2015, the fund gave $450,000 over 3 years to [[Creative Commons]]. to develop tools that complement current CC licence suite.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Creative Commons awarded $450,000 from the Arcadia Fund to support open access publishing for authors

column1: In September 2017, the fund gave $5 million to the [[Wikimedia Foundation]], the largest contribution to the foundation at the time.   <ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Matching gift grows Wikimedia Endowment by $10 million – Wikimedia Blog
column5: access-date=2019-05-04}}</ref> It gave another $3.5 million   in 2019<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=Peter Baldwin, Lisbet Rausing give an additional $3.5 million to the Wikimedia Endowment

column1: The Arcadia Fund in 2015 gave $25 million to [[Yale University]] to renovate the Yale Hall of Graduates Studies enabling the university to co-locate the dispersed humanities departments to under one roof. offering a setting for cross-disciplinary collaboration and advance research. .<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Gift to transform Hall of Graduate Studies honors David Swensen
column7: access-date=2019-05-28}}</ref> Baldwin and Rausing have asked in tribute to the service of [[David F. Swensen
column8: David Swensen]] (Who built Yale's endowment from $1.3 billion to $23.9 billion) that the building should be named after him.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Yale to name building after Swensen

column1: Arcadia gave £5 million to the illuminated River Foundation in 2017 <ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Multi-million pound donation gives Illuminated River project the green light for next year
column5: access-date=2019-05-31}}</ref>towards its program for a commissioned art installation of light to 15 of Central London's bridges along the River Thames. When the project is completed it would be the longest art commission in the world at 2.5 miles long.  ref>{{Cite web

column1: The fund before 2009 were involved in supporting  human rights,  supporting organisations to help refugee scholars, educate disadvantaged children in Africa, and conduct women's right advocacy. In 2005, it provided a $5 million grant to the Mvule Trust, to provide bursaries to young women in Uganda   to attend secondary school. The grant and trust gave 75% of scholarships to girls and by 2007 and the trust had supported the education of 1,868 children.<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web

Arcadia has provided a total of $6 million in 2005-06  to the Human Rights Watch (US)  to help their empirical research into persecution of women, and its fact gathering, press releases, advocacy and lobbying .<ref name=\":2\" /> .<ref name=\":5\" />

column3: School of Oriental and African Studies]]

column2: The Academic Programme to train linguists documenting endangered languages.
Cambridge Conservation Initiative:  Endangered Landscapes Programme
To develop and support large-scale projects seeking to create habitats that are rich in biodiversity and resilient to environmental change.
Halcyon Programmes and core institutional support
To  expand the success of both the Halcyon Land & Sea Fund and the Halcyon Marine Programme to date, increasing focus on long-term sustainability.
Institute for the Preservation of Cultural Heritage
To build a new cultural conservation and digitisation centre.
To refurbish the Hall of Graduate Studies and to support the programmatic agenda that will transform it into a central home for the humanities at Yale
To establish a  grants programme that funds projects that  digitise neglected, vulnerable or inaccessible archives relating to  pre-industrial societies.
School of Oriental  and African Studies
To continue to support the Endangered Languages Documentation Programme.
To support  Harvard College Fellows Program.
To establish the Endowed History Department Chair and History Department Chair Quasi-Endowment  Fund.
Cambridge Conservation Initiative: Endowment of Directorship
To establish an endowment fund for the Cambridge Conservation Initiative Directorship.
Supporting Open Access with Harvard Library
To improve acquisition policies and access to the library's collections.

column1: The Table Breakdowns Arcadia largest grants and a description of the purpose of the grant<ref name=\":2\" />
The graph shows Arcadia's cumulative grant total<ref name=\":2\" />
<!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. -->
[[Category:Charities based in the United Kingdom]]",Arcadia Fund,//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arcadia_Fund
'''''Rings''''' (known in Japan as '''''The Ring: Rebirth''''') is a 2017 American [[Supernatural horror film
column2: supernatural]] [[horror film]] directed by [[F. Javier Gutiérrez]], written by [[David Loucka]], [[Jacob Aaron Estes]] and [[Akiva Goldsman]] and starring [[Matilda Lutz]], [[Alex Roe]], [[Johnny Galecki]], [[Aimee Teegarden]], [[Bonnie Morgan]] and [[Vincent D'Onofrio]]. It is the third installment in [[The Ring (franchise)
column3: ''The Ring'' series]], following the previous installments ''[[The Ring (2002 film)
column4: The Ring]]'' (2002) and ''[[The Ring Two]]'' (2005), and is based on elements of ''[[Spiral (Suzuki novel)

column1: [[Paramount Pictures]] had initially planned a third film, originally titled ''The Ring 3D'', in early 2014, with Gutiérrez signed to direct the film from a screenplay written by Goldsman, Loucka, and Aaron Estes. [[Principal photography]] began on March 23, 2015, in [[Atlanta]], and wrapped on May 31, 2015. Reshoots took place in July 2016.

''Rings'' was released in the United States on February 3, 2017, and opened #2 in the box office. The film received generally negative reviews from critics, with many criticizing its story, plot points and [[jump scare
column2: jump scares]], but praised Lutz's performance. It has grossed $83{{nbsp}}million worldwide against its $25{{nbsp}}million budget.

column1: Ten years after the events of [[The Ring (2002 film)
column3: Rings]], and [[The Ring Two]], on an airplane bound for [[Seattle]], a man reveals that he has watched [[Samara Morgan]]'s cursed [[videotape]]. Another passenger reveals she has seen the tape too and asks the man if he made a copy; he replies that he did not. Moments later, Samara causes the airplane to crash.

column1: Two years later in 2015, college professor Gabriel Brown buys a [[Videocassette recorder
column2: VCR]], discovering the videotape inside. Elsewhere, student Julia sees her boyfriend Holt off to college but grows concerned when he falls out of contact. She is inspired to find him when a panicked girl contacts her, asking for Holt's whereabouts. Julia meets Gabriel and finds a group of people known as the Sevens, who are involved in an experiment involving the cursed video. The group films themselves watching the video before passing the footage to another person called a \"tail\".

column1: Julia recognizes the panicked girl, Skye, who takes her to her apartment to have her watch the video, but Holt warns her not to. Julia locks herself in the bathroom as Samara kills Skye. Holt reveals that he has watched the tape as well and has 12 hours left. Julia watches his copy and when she picks up the phone, she experiences a vision of a door. The phone burns a mark on her hand. Julia's version of the video cannot be copied and contains additional images of a mysterious woman: she realizes they must [[cremate]] Samara's physical remains.
Gabriel sends them to Sacrament Valley, where Samara was given a proper burial after the residents of Moesko Island refused to accept the remains.{{refn
column3: As depicted in the 2002 film ''[[The Ring (2002 film)
column4: The Ring]]''.}} He realizes the mark on Julia's hand is [[Braille]], translates it, and goes to warn them. Julia and Holt find an unmarked tomb, but when they break in, they find it empty. They are caught and taken to a blind man named Galen Burke, who claims Samara's body was entombed by the local priest but a flood came, leading the priest to bury her in a [[potter's field]] outside town.

column1: Heading for the field, Julia and Holt are stopped due to a car crash and learn Gabriel was involved. He tries to warn Julia of his discovery but is killed by a falling [[utility pole]]. After experiencing a vision of Samara's mother Evelyn, Julia and Holt return to town. Julia goes to the church and discovers a hidden chamber beneath the bell tower, finding evidence that Evelyn was imprisoned there while pregnant, held in captivity by the priest after being raped before she escaped eight months into the pregnancy.

Julia visits Burke and explains her findings. He attacks her, revealing he is the priest as well as Samara's biological father, having blinded himself to escape the reach of her powers. Julia pushes him down the stairs, temporarily incapacitating him. Holt rushes to Burke's house, where he is knocked unconscious. Julia discovers Samara's skeleton behind a wall, and Burke tries to strangle her to prevent her from cremating Samara's remains. He claims the cremation would unleash an unspeakable evil upon the world, and that he has killed several people who previously attempted to do the same. Suddenly, a swarm of [[cicada]]s fly in, summoning Samara through Julia's phone. Samara cures Burke's blindness and kills him. Holt recovers and rushes to Julia's aid. That night, he and Julia cremate Samara's corpse, in an attempt to appease her spirit once and for all, and return home.

While Julia is in the shower, Holt notices a voicemail from Gabriel, who warns him of the Braille, which Holt begins to translate. In the bathroom, Julia peels away the skin where the mark was, revealing grey skin underneath. She begins to cough up black hair, from which a cicada is born. Meanwhile, Julia's copy of the cursed video is sent to everyone on her contact list, which becomes [[Viral video
column2: viral]], despite Holt's futile attempts to disconnect the computer. As his computer glitches, the Braille translation is revealed to be \"[[resurrection
column3: rebirth]]\", as Samara is reborn in Julia, seeing Samara's face in her mirror instead of her own.

In 2014, Paramount Pictures announced the initially titled ''The Ring 3D'', with [[F. Javier Gutiérrez]] directing.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Paramount Sets F. Javier Gutiérrez To Helm 'Ring' Threequel
column6: Paramount]] was in talks with [[Akiva Goldsman]] to write a third draft of the screenplay, which had previously been worked on by [[David Loucka]] and [[Jacob Aaron Estes]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: accessdate=November 29, 2014}}</ref> In November, Gutiérrez posted an [[Instagram]] photo that showed that the title of the sequel had been changed to ''Rings''.<ref>{{cite web

column1: On January 16, 2015, [[Matilda Lutz]] was cast in the lead role.<ref name=LutzCast>{{cite news
column4: title=Paramount's 'The Ring' Reboot 'Rings' Casts Newcomer as Female Lead (Exclusive)
column8: date=January 16, 2015}}</ref> [[Alex Roe]] was cast as the male lead on March 20, 2015.<ref name=RoeCast>{{cite news
column15: date=March 20, 2015}}</ref> [[Aimee Teegarden]] joined the cast on March 27, 2015,<ref name=TeegardenCast>{{cite news
column18: title=Aimee Teegarden Joins Paramount's 'Rings'; Clemens Schick To Menace 'The Lake'
column22: date=March 27, 2015}}</ref> and [[Johnny Galecki]] signed on to star in the film on April 1, 2015, playing Gabriel, a professor who mentors and helps both Holt and Julia.<ref name=GaleckiCast>{{cite news
column25: title=Johnny Galecki Hooks On To Paramount's Horror Threequel 'Rings'

column1: [[Principal photography]] on the film began on March 23, 2015, in [[Atlanta]], and wrapped on May 31, 2015.<ref name=\"comingsoon.net\">{{cite news
column4: title=Production Begins on Horror Sequel Rings
column8: date=March 23, 2015}}</ref> Reshoots took place in July 2016.

column6: accessdate=December 14, 2016}}</ref> and was concluded in November 2016.<ref>{{cite web

column1: [[Paramount Pictures]] originally set the film for a November 13, 2015, release,<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Paramount Sets 'Rings' for Nov. 13, Moves Back 'Paranormal Activity'
column8: date=January 27, 2015}}</ref> but in September 2015, the film was pulled from the schedule,<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=\"RINGS\" To Usher In New Halloween Release Staple?
column15: accessdate=September 26, 2016}}</ref> and in October 2015, Paramount rescheduled the release date to April 1, 2016.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=Paramount Delays Horror Pics 'Friday The 13th' – Again – And Threequel 'Rings'
column22: date=October 20, 2015}}</ref> On February 17, 2016, the film was rescheduled for release on October 28, 2016, to take the place of Paramount's previous October horror release staple, the ''[[Paranormal Activity (film series)
column23: Paranormal Activity]]'' series, which ended in 2015 with ''[[Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column25: title=\"RINGS\" To Usher In New Halloween Release Staple?
column33: url-status=dead}}</ref> On September 22, 2016, the film was delayed to February 3, 2017, most likely to avoid competition with ''[[Ouija: Origin of Evil]]'', leaving the latter as the only horror film that debuted around Halloween 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column35: title=Paramount Pictures Moves 'Rings' Again, This Time To February
column42: title=The Ring' Threequel Delayed for the Third Time by Paramount

column2: trailer]] was released on August 24, 2016. The second trailer was released on January 5, 2017, alongside a new international trailer, containing new footage. In January 2017, Paramount released a prank video where an actress dressed as Samara jumped out of a television to scare unwitting patrons at an electronics store. The video garnered 200{{nbsp}}million views in 24 hours on [[Facebook]].<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=The Story Behind the Pants-Soiling 'Rings' Prank That Has 200 Million Views in 24 Hours

column1: Rings was released on digital HD on April 21 and on Blu-ray and DVD on May 2, 2017. The digital HD and Blu-ray releases include behind-the-scenes interviews with the cast & crew, deleted/extended scenes, and an alternate ending.<ref>{{cite web

''Rings'' grossed $27.8{{nbsp}}million in the United States and Canada and $55.3{{nbsp}}million in other territories for a worldwide total of $83.1{{nbsp}}million, against a production budget of $25{{nbsp}}million.<ref name=BOM>{{cite web
In North America, the film was released alongside ''[[The Space Between Us (film)
column2: The Space Between Us]]'' and ''[[The Comedian (2016 film)
column3: The Comedian]]'', and was projected to gross $12–14{{nbsp}}million from about 3,000 theaters in its opening weekend.<ref name=\"preview\">{{cite web
column5: title='Rings' Hopes To Choke 'Split' In Genre Scrimmage Over Super Bowl Weekend – Box Office
column6: website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]}}</ref> It made $800,000 from its Thursday night previews.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title='Split' Looks to Fend Off 'Rings' and 'Space Between Us' Over Super Bowl Weekend
column9: work=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> It went on to open to $13{{nbsp}}million, finishing second at the box office behind fellow horror film ''[[Split (2016 American film)
column12: title='Split' Dings 'Rings'; Auds Keep Distance From 'Space'; 'Comedian' Bombs: Sunday Update

column1: On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 8% based on 111 reviews and an average rating of 3.19/10, becoming the worst rated film of the trilogy. The site's critical consensus reads, \"''Rings'' may offer ardent fans of the franchise a few threadbare thrills, but for everyone else, it may feel like an endless loop of muddled mythology and rehashed plot points.\"<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=September 6, 2019}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 25 out of 100 based on 23 critics, indicating \"generally unfavorable reviews\".<ref>{{cite web
column10: accessdate=February 10, 2017}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of \"C–\" on an A+ to F scale, lower than the B– and C+ earned by its respective predecessors.<ref name=\"CinemaScore\">{{cite web

column1: Alex Gilyadov of [[IGN]] gave the film a score 4.5/10, stating that it \"opts for lazy jump scares and a convoluted origins story no one asked for or needed\", though not dismissing that it has \"some chilling scenes and creepy visuals\".<ref>{{cite news
column8: date=3 February 2017}}</ref> [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave the movie zero stars and called it a \"botch job\" that suffers from \"demo-worthy awfulness in directing, writing and acting\".<ref>{{cite news
column12: title='Rings' Review: Latest Entry in Haunted-Video Franchise May Kill You With Boredom
column16: date=3 February 2017}}</ref> Peter Sobczynski of [[RogerEbert.com]] gave a single star, calling it \"More wearying than frightening\".<ref>{{cite news
column23: date=3 February 2017}}</ref> A.A. Dowd of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' commented that the film was a pale imitation of [[The Ring (2002 film)
column24: the 2002 American remake]] in terms of visuals and plot structure. He also dismissed the film's characters as \"bland nothings\", citing their lack of development in the story.<ref>{{cite news
column27: title=Samara goes digital in Rings, but this is still just a faded copy of last decade's scares

column1: Some critics applauded the film out of the US. Mike McCahill of ''[[The Guardian]]'' commented that the film \"smoothly reinvents the wheel\" and \"the director has fun with the franchise's organising visual conceit and handles the setpieces with quiet aplomb\", pointing that \"the admirably loopy finale, involving blind Vincent d'Onofrio's swarming army of cicadas, is worthy of one of the better ''[[The Exorcist
column5: title=Spooky Ringu reboot smoothly reinvents the wheel (2017)
column9: date=3 February 2017}}</ref> Javier Jimenez Montoya of [[Vavel]] also praised the film, stating that \"it's a step forward in the horror genre\" and applauding \"its strong, surprising ending\".<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Critica de Rings, un paso hacia delante (2017)

column1: The generally negative critical reception in the US, along with its lower-than-expected US box office intake, was partially blamed by some critics and fans for the cancellation of Paramount's newest installment of the [[Friday the 13th (franchise)
column4: title='Friday the 13th' Reboot Axed by Paramount

column1: Speaking at CinemaCon, Paramount Vice Chairman [[Rob Moore (executive)
column2: Rob Moore]] said that should the film prove successful, more sequels could recur annually, taking the place of Paramount's ''[[Paranormal Activity]]'' series.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=CinemaCon: Paramount Pictures Teases Upcoming Slate
column6: work=Coming Soon}}</ref> These plans were left in doubt following Moore's departure from the company.<ref>{{Cite news
column8: title=Rob Moore Out at Paramount Pictures (EXCLUSIVE)
column14: language=en-US}}</ref> In a post-release interview, Moore's successor, Megan Colligan, said that \"time will tell\" if another sequel is in the cards.<ref>{{Cite news
column16: title=Box Office: 'Split' Tops 'Rings,' as 'Space Between Us' Bombs
column19: access-date=2017-04-22}}</ref> Following Colligan's departure, there has been no update on a sequel.<ref>{{Cite news
column21: title=Jim Gianopulos Statement To Paramount Employees: Interim Team In Place After Megan Colligan Exit

column2: The Grudge]]'' director [[Nicolas Pesce]] expressed interest in a [[Crossover (fiction)#Film
column3: crossover film]] between ''The Grudge'' and the [[The Ring (franchise)#American film series

column1: On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 8% based on 111 reviews and an average rating of 3.19/10, becoming the worst rated film of the trilogy. The site's critical consensus reads, \"''Rings'' may offer ardent fans of the franchise a few threadbare thrills, but for everyone else, it may feel like an endless loop of muddled mythology and rehashed plot points.\"<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=September 6, 2019}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 25 out of 100 based on 23 critics, indicating \"generally unfavorable reviews\".<ref>{{cite web
column10: accessdate=February 10, 2017}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of \"C–\" on an A+ to F scale, lower than the B– and C+ earned by its respective predecessors.<ref name=\"CinemaScore\">{{cite web

column1: Alex Gilyadov of [[IGN]] gave the film a score 4.5/10, stating that it \"opts for lazy jump scares and a convoluted origins story no one asked for or needed\", though not dismissing that it has \"some chilling scenes and creepy visuals\".<ref>{{cite news

'''''Rings''''' (known in Japan as '''''The Ring: Rebirth''''') is a 2017 American [[Supernatural horror film
column2: supernatural]] [[horror film]] directed by [[F. Javier Gutiérrez]], written by [[David Loucka]], [[Jacob Aaron Estes]] and [[Akiva Goldsman]] and starring [[Matilda Lutz]], [[Alex Roe]], [[Johnny Galecki]], [[Aimee Teegarden]], [[Bonnie Morgan]] and [[Vincent D'Onofrio]]. It is the third installment in [[The Ring (franchise)
column3: ''The Ring'' series]], following the previous installments ''[[The Ring (2002 film)
column4: The Ring]]'' (2002) and ''[[The Ring Two]]'' (2005), and is based on elements of ''[[Spiral (Suzuki novel)

column1: [[Paramount Pictures]] had initially planned a third film, originally titled ''The Ring 3D'', in early 2014, with Gutiérrez signed to direct the film from a screenplay written by Goldsman, Loucka, and Aaron Estes. [[Principal photography]] began on March 23, 2015, in [[Atlanta]], and wrapped on May 31, 2015. Reshoots took place in July 2016.

''Rings'' was released in the United States on February 3, 2017, and opened #2 in the box office. The film received generally negative reviews from critics, with many criticizing its story, plot points and [[jump scare
column2: jump scares]], but praised Lutz's performance. It has grossed $83{{nbsp}}million worldwide against its $25{{nbsp}}million budget.

column1: Ten years after the events of [[The Ring (2002 film)
column3: Rings]], and [[The Ring Two]], on an airplane bound for [[Seattle]], a man reveals that he has watched [[Samara Morgan]]'s cursed [[videotape]]. Another passenger reveals she has seen the tape too and asks the man if he made a copy; he replies that he did not. Moments later, Samara causes the airplane to crash.

column1: Two years later in 2015, college professor Gabriel Brown buys a [[Videocassette recorder
column2: VCR]], discovering the videotape inside. Elsewhere, student Julia sees her boyfriend Holt off to college but grows concerned when he falls out of contact. She is inspired to find him when a panicked girl contacts her, asking for Holt's whereabouts. Julia meets Gabriel and finds a group of people known as the Sevens, who are involved in an experiment involving the cursed video. The group films themselves watching the video before passing the footage to another person called a \"tail\".

column1: Julia recognizes the panicked girl, Skye, who takes her to her apartment to have her watch the video, but Holt warns her not to. Julia locks herself in the bathroom as Samara kills Skye. Holt reveals that he has watched the tape as well and has 12 hours left. Julia watches his copy and when she picks up the phone, she experiences a vision of a door. The phone burns a mark on her hand. Julia's version of the video cannot be copied and contains additional images of a mysterious woman: she realizes they must [[cremate]] Samara's physical remains.

Gabriel sends them to Sacrament Valley, where Samara was given a proper burial after the residents of Moesko Island refused to accept the remains. He realizes the mark on Julia's hand is [[Braille]], translates it, and goes to warn them. Julia and Holt find an unmarked tomb, but when they break in, they find it empty. They are caught and taken to a blind man named Galen Burke, who claims Samara's body was entombed by the local priest but a flood came, leading the priest to bury her in a [[potter's field]] outside town.

Heading for the field, Julia and Holt are stopped due to a car crash and learn Gabriel was involved. He tries to warn Julia of his discovery but is killed by a falling [[utility pole]]. After experiencing a vision of Samara's mother Evelyn, Julia and Holt return to town. Julia goes to the church and discovers a hidden chamber beneath the bell tower, finding evidence that Evelyn was imprisoned there while pregnant, held in captivity by the priest after being raped before she escaped eight months into the pregnancy.

Julia visits Burke and explains her findings. He attacks her, revealing he is the priest as well as Samara's biological father, having blinded himself to escape the reach of her powers. Julia pushes him down the stairs, temporarily incapacitating him. Holt rushes to Burke's house, where he is knocked unconscious. Julia discovers Samara's skeleton behind a wall, and Burke tries to strangle her to prevent her from cremating Samara's remains. He claims the cremation would unleash an unspeakable evil upon the world, and that he has killed several people who previously attempted to do the same. Suddenly, a swarm of [[cicada]]s fly in, summoning Samara through Julia's phone. Samara cures Burke's blindness and kills him. Holt recovers and rushes to Julia's aid. That night, he and Julia cremate Samara's corpse, in an attempt to appease her spirit once and for all, and return home.

While Julia is in the shower, Holt notices a voicemail from Gabriel, who warns him of the Braille, which Holt begins to translate. In the bathroom, Julia peels away the skin where the mark was, revealing grey skin underneath. She begins to cough up black hair, from which a cicada is born. Meanwhile, Julia's copy of the cursed video is sent to everyone on her contact list, which becomes [[Viral video
column2: viral]], despite Holt's futile attempts to disconnect the computer. As his computer glitches, the Braille translation is revealed to be \"[[resurrection
column3: rebirth]]\", as Samara is reborn in Julia, seeing Samara's face in her mirror instead of her own.

column22: date=October 20, 2015}}</ref> On February 17, 2016, the film was rescheduled for release on October 28, 2016, to take the place of Paramount's previous October horror release staple, the ''[[Paranormal Activity (film series)
column23: Paranormal Activity]]'' series, which ended in 2015 with ''[[Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column25: title=\"RINGS\" To Usher In New Halloween Release Staple?
column33: url-status=dead}}</ref> On September 22, 2016, the film was delayed to February 3, 2017, most likely to avoid competition with ''[[Ouija: Origin of Evil]]'', leaving the latter as the only horror film that debuted around Halloween 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column35: title=Paramount Pictures Moves 'Rings' Again, This Time To February
column42: title=The Ring' Threequel Delayed for the Third Time by Paramount

column2: trailer]] was released on August 24, 2016. The second trailer was released on January 5, 2017, alongside a new international trailer, containing new footage. In January 2017, Paramount released a prank video where an actress dressed as Samara jumped out of a television to scare unwitting patrons at an electronics store. The video garnered 200{{nbsp}}million views in 24 hours on [[Facebook]].<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=The Story Behind the Pants-Soiling 'Rings' Prank That Has 200 Million Views in 24 Hours

column1: Rings was released on digital HD on April 21 and on Blu-ray and DVD on May 2, 2017. The digital HD and Blu-ray releases include behind-the-scenes interviews with the cast & crew, deleted/extended scenes, and an alternate ending.<ref>{{cite web

''Rings'' grossed $27.8{{nbsp}}million in the United States and Canada and $55.3{{nbsp}}million in other territories for a worldwide total of $83.1{{nbsp}}million, against a production budget of $25{{nbsp}}million.<ref name=BOM>{{cite web
In North America, the film was released alongside ''[[The Space Between Us (film)
column2: The Space Between Us]]'' and ''[[The Comedian (2016 film)
column3: The Comedian]]'', and was projected to gross $12–14{{nbsp}}million from about 3,000 theaters in its opening weekend.<ref name=\"preview\">{{cite web
column5: title='Rings' Hopes To Choke 'Split' In Genre Scrimmage Over Super Bowl Weekend – Box Office
column6: website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]}}</ref> It made $800,000 from its Thursday night previews.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title='Split' Looks to Fend Off 'Rings' and 'Space Between Us' Over Super Bowl Weekend
column9: work=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> It went on to open to $13{{nbsp}}million, finishing second at the box office behind fellow horror film ''[[Split (2016 American film)
column12: title='Split' Dings 'Rings'; Auds Keep Distance From 'Space'; 'Comedian' Bombs: Sunday Update

column1: On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 8% based on 111 reviews and an average rating of 3.19/10, becoming the worst rated film of the trilogy. The site's critical consensus reads, \"''Rings'' may offer ardent fans of the franchise a few threadbare thrills, but for everyone else, it may feel like an endless loop of muddled mythology and rehashed plot points.\"<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=September 6, 2019}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 25 out of 100 based on 23 critics, indicating \"generally unfavorable reviews\".<ref>{{cite web
column10: accessdate=February 10, 2017}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of \"C–\" on an A+ to F scale, lower than the B– and C+ earned by its respective predecessors.<ref name=\"CinemaScore\">{{cite web

column1: Alex Gilyadov of [[IGN]] gave the film a score 4.5/10, stating that it \"opts for lazy jump scares and a convoluted origins story no one asked for or needed\", though not dismissing that it has \"some chilling scenes and creepy visuals\".<ref>{{cite news
column8: date=3 February 2017}}</ref> [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave the movie zero stars and called it a \"botch job\" that suffers from \"demo-worthy awfulness in directing, writing and acting\".<ref>{{cite news
column12: title='Rings' Review: Latest Entry in Haunted-Video Franchise May Kill You With Boredom
column16: date=3 February 2017}}</ref> Peter Sobczynski of [[RogerEbert.com]] gave a single star, calling it \"More wearying than frightening\".<ref>{{cite news
column23: date=3 February 2017}}</ref> A.A. Dowd of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' commented that the film was a pale imitation of [[The Ring (2002 film)
column24: the 2002 American remake]] in terms of visuals and plot structure. He also dismissed the film's characters as \"bland nothings\", citing their lack of development in the story.<ref>{{cite news
column27: title=Samara goes digital in Rings, but this is still just a faded copy of last decade's scares

column1: Some critics applauded the film out of the US. Mike McCahill of ''[[The Guardian]]'' commented that the film \"smoothly reinvents the wheel\" and \"the director has fun with the franchise's organising visual conceit and handles the setpieces with quiet aplomb\", pointing that \"the admirably loopy finale, involving blind Vincent d'Onofrio's swarming army of cicadas, is worthy of one of the better ''[[The Exorcist
column5: title=Spooky Ringu reboot smoothly reinvents the wheel (2017)
column9: date=3 February 2017}}</ref> Javier Jimenez Montoya of [[Vavel]] also praised the film, stating that \"it's a step forward in the horror genre\" and applauding \"its strong, surprising ending\".<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Critica de Rings, un paso hacia delante (2017)

column1: The generally negative critical reception in the US, along with its lower-than-expected US box office intake, was partially blamed by some critics and fans for the cancellation of Paramount's newest installment of the [[Friday the 13th (franchise)
column4: title='Friday the 13th' Reboot Axed by Paramount

column1: Speaking at CinemaCon, Paramount Vice Chairman [[Rob Moore (executive)
column2: Rob Moore]] said that should the film prove successful, more sequels could recur annually, taking the place of Paramount's ''[[Paranormal Activity]]'' series.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=CinemaCon: Paramount Pictures Teases Upcoming Slate
column6: work=Coming Soon}}</ref> These plans were left in doubt following Moore's departure from the company.<ref>{{Cite news
column8: title=Rob Moore Out at Paramount Pictures (EXCLUSIVE)
column14: language=en-US}}</ref> In a post-release interview, Moore's successor, Megan Colligan, said that \"time will tell\" if another sequel is in the cards.<ref>{{Cite news
column16: title=Box Office: 'Split' Tops 'Rings,' as 'Space Between Us' Bombs
column19: access-date=2017-04-22}}</ref> Following Colligan's departure, there has been no update on a sequel.<ref>{{Cite news
column21: title=Jim Gianopulos Statement To Paramount Employees: Interim Team In Place After Megan Colligan Exit

column2: The Grudge]]'' director [[Nicolas Pesce]] expressed interest in a [[Crossover (fiction)#Film
column3: crossover film]] between ''The Grudge'' and the [[The Ring (franchise)#American film series

column7: title= Información para el desarrollo sostenible: Argentina y la Agenda 2030

column2: miˈsjones}}, ''Missions'') is one of the [[Provinces of Argentina
column3: 23 provinces]] of [[Argentina]], located in the northeastern corner of the country in the [[Mesopotamia, Argentina
column5: surrounded]] by [[Paraguay]] to the northwest, [[Brazil]] to the north, east and south, and [[Corrientes Province]] of Argentina to the southwest.

column1: This was an early area of [[Roman Catholic]] [[missionary]] activity by the [[Society of Jesus]] in what was then called the Province of Paraguay, beginning in the early 17th century. In 1984 the ruins of four mission sites in Argentina were designated [[World Heritage Sites]] by UNESCO.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Instruccion practica para ordenar santamente la vidà; que ofrece el P. Antonio Garriga de la Compania de Iesus. Como brebe memorial, y recuerdo à los que hazen los exercicios espirituales de S. Ignacio de Loyola fundador de la misma Compañia
column7: trans-title=Practical Instruction to Order One’s Life According to Saintly Precepts: Offered by Father Antonio Garriga of the Society of Jesus. As a Brief Memorial and Memento of the Spiritual Exercises of Saint Ignatius Loyola, Founder of the Society

column1: [[Image:Ruins of the São Miguel das Missões.jpg
column5: 1846 impression of [[San Ignacio Miní]], a Jesuit Reduction, abandoned following the temporary abolition of the order in 1773.]]

column1: Indigenous peoples of various cultures lived in the area of the future province for thousands of years. At the time of European encounter, it was occupied by the [[Kaingang]] and [[Xokleng people
column2: Xokleng]], later followed by the [[Guarani people
column3: Guarani]]. The first European to visit the region, [[Sebastian Cabot (explorer)
column4: Sebastian Cabot]], discovered Apipé Falls while navigating the [[Paraná River]] in December 1527. In 1541 [[Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca]] reached the [[Iguazu Falls

column1: In the 17th century, members of the [[Society of Jesus]] came to the region as missionaries. They began to establish a string of [[Jesuit Reductions
column2: Jesuit ''Reductions'']], most notably that of [[San Ignacio Miní
column3: San Ignacio]]. In a few years they set up 30 mission villages. They taught the Guarani western-style agriculture and crafts. Their crafts were sold and traded along the river and they shared in the Reductions' prosperity.

column2: Portuguese]] government, at the insistence of its anti-Jesuit [[Secretary of State]], the [[Marquis de Pombal]], ordered all Reductions closed in [[colonial Brazil
column3: its territory]] (which then included much of present-day Misiones Province). The Marquis eventually prevailed in 1773 on Pope [[Clement XIV]] to have the Jesuit Order [[Suppression of the Jesuits
column4: suppressed]].  With the abandoning of the missions, the prosperous trade surrounding these Reductions quickly vanished. Colonists imposed a brutal [[plantation]] economy in the region, forcing the Guarani to act as slave labor.

column5: Steamer on the riverbank at Posadas, 1892.]]

column1: In 1814, [[Gervasio Posadas]], the [[Supreme Director of the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata
column2: Director]] of the [[United Provinces of the Rio de la Plata]], declared Misiones annexed to Argentina's [[Corrientes Province
column3: Corrientes]] (at this time Argentina was quasi-independent but nominally still a Spanish colony). Argentina did not exert ''de facto'' control over Misiones, which was claimed by several countries and effectively governed itself. In 1830 Argentine military forces from [[Corrientes Province]] took control of Misiones.

column1: In 1838 [[Paraguay]] occupied Misiones, claiming the area on the basis that the Misiones population consisted of indigenous Guarani, the major ethnic group of Paraguay. In 1865 Paraguayan forces invaded Misiones again in what became the [[Paraguayan War
column2: War of the Triple Alliance]] (1864–1870). Following the defeat of Paraguay and its peace agreement with Argentina (eventually signed in 1876), Paraguay gave up its claim to the Misiones territory.

column1: Although Argentina had claimed Misiones since 1814, academics tend to interpret Argentine possession of Misiones as beginning with the defeat of Paraguay in the War of the Triple Alliance. Bethell writes that \"the [[Treaty of the Triple Alliance
column2: treaty of alliance]] [i.e. against Paraguay] contained secret clauses providing for the annexation of disputed territory in northern Paraguay by Brazil and regions in the east and west of Paraguay by Argentina... After a long and harrowing war (1865–70), Argentina got it from a prostrate Paraguay territory in Misiones.\"<ref>Bethell ''Argentina since Independence'' [[Cambridge University Press]], 1993, pp. 45–6</ref> Scobie states that \"the political status of Misiones remained vague\" and that Argentina gained the region \"as a by-product of the Paraguayan war in the 1860s\".<ref>Scobie ''Argentina'' [[Oxford University Press]], 1964, pages 22–3</ref>

column1: [[Image:Ukranian immigrants cropping yerba mate in Tres Capones, Misiones.jpg
column6: Ukrainian]] immigrants harvest [[yerba mate]] in 1920. Despite challenging conditions, Misiones attracted considerable European immigration in the early 20th-century.]]

column2: War of the Triple Alliance]] left Paraguay much impoverished, and Misiones benefited economically from belonging to Argentina. In 1876 the Argentine President [[Nicolás Avellaneda]], assisted by his close friend, General Pietro Canestro (an Italian nobleman who devoted much of his life and wealth to the achievement and sustainability of the peace in the region), proclaimed the [[Immigration in Argentina
column3: Immigration and Colonization Law]]. This law fostered the immigration of European colonists in order to populate the vast unspoiled Argentinian territories.

column1: Several colonizing companies formed under this law. One of them, Adolf Schwelm's ''Eldorado Colonización y Explotación de Bosques Ltda. S.A.'', founded the city of [[Eldorado, Misiones
column2: Eldorado]] in 1919 with a port on the Upper Paraná. Its agricultural colonies and experimental farms, the orange- and grapefruit-tree plantations, and the cultivation of yerba mate, the mills and the dryers for such product are characteristic of this area. [[Swedish-Argentines]] became well known for growing [[yerba mate]].

column1: Misiones received many immigrants, mostly from Europe, coming mainly via Southern Brazil. Some came from Buenos Aires, and from Eastern Europe, in particular large numbers of [[Polish minority in Argentina
column4: date=February 2016}}, Misiones has continued to benefit economically and has developed politically within Argentina. It has been successfully integrated into the Argentine state.{{citation needed
column6: 2016}} control of the province is not contested. On December 10, 1953 the \"National Territory of Misiones\" gained [[provinces of Argentina
column7: provincial]] status in accordance with Law 14.294, and its constitution was approved on April 21, 1958.

column1: Misiones received more attention from national policy-makers following an international agreement (1973) to construct the [[Yacyretá]] hydroelectric dam on a point in the [[Paraná River]] shared by Paraguay and Corrientes Province. When the dam became fully operative in the 1990s, the Paraná's waters all along the Misiones shores rose. They flooded lands that the dam's authorities had failed to clear and condition adequately, resulting in the onset of mosquito-transmitted illnesses, such as [[leishmaniasis]], [[yellow fever]], [[dengue]], and [[malaria]]. The entire Misiones shores along the Paraná River is now confined by two dams, one of them Yaciretá, downstream of the river, and the other [[Itaipu dam
column2: Itaipú]], located in Brazil and Paraguay, upstream of the river and north of [[Puerto Iguazú]]. {{As of
column3: 2016}} Argentina is pursuing an agreement with Paraguay to expand the reservoir works in order to double the facility's [[Electricity sector in Argentina

column1: Misiones is the second smallest province after [[Tucumán Province
[[File:Misiones - Parque provincial Salto Encantado desde ruta 7 (2).jpg

The Misiones plateau includes a part of Brazil across the border. The rocks contain significant quantities of iron which forms a part of the soil, giving it a reddish color. At the center of the plateau rises the Sierra de Misiones, its highest peak, 843 m, near Bernardo de Irigoyen, in the Cerro Rincón.
The province is embraced by three big rivers including the [[Paraná River
column4: Iguazú]]. [[Iguazu Falls]] are spectacular [[waterfall]]s on the Iguazú River in the northwest corner of the province, near the city of [[Puerto Iguazú]]. Misiones shares the falls with the Brazilian state of [[Paraná (state)
column5: Paraná]] (in that nation's Southern Region). Meanwhile, the international border with [[Paraguay]] is close by.

column1: The province has a [[humid subtropical climate]] characterized by a lack of a dry season and abundant rainfall throughout the year.<ref name=turismoclima>{{cite web
column8: accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> Under the [[Köppen climate classification]], it is classified as ''Cfa''.<ref name=IRNclima>{{cite web
column13: publisher=Secretaria de Mineria de la Nacion (Argentina)
column15: accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> There are four distinct seasons although winters and autumns are fairly short.<ref name=IRNclima/> The mean annual temperature is around {{convert
column19: 0}}.<ref name=turismoclima/> June–August typically register the coldest days when temperatures can fall below {{convert
column23: 0}}.<ref name=turismoclima/> However, rare incursions of polar air into the province from the south can lead to frost.<ref name=IRNclima/> Summers are hot with temperatures exceeding {{convert
column27: 0}} from December to February.<ref name=turismoclima/> One of the main characteristic is the presence of hills in the central and northern parts of the province leading to lower temperatures as a result of the higher elevation.<ref name=IRNclima/> Average annual rainfall ranges from a low of {{convert
column38: p=185}} The rainfall pattern in the province has a [[bimodal]] distribution with two peaks occurring in Spring and Autumn with winters being the driest.{{sfn
column41: p=185}} The exceptions are the north and higher altitude areas where precipitation is well distributed throughout the year.{{sfn
column44: p=185}} Snowfall has occurred at the higher hills.<ref name=IRNclima/> For example, during the winter of 1975, snowfall was observed and accumulated in Bernando de Irigoyen, one of the coldest towns in the province due to its high altitude {{convert
column48: abbr=on}}.<ref name=IRNclima/> Owing to the humid climate and high rainfall, relative humidity is high.<ref name=IRNclima/>

column1: The vegetation is the so-called \"{{Interlanguage link multi
column4: 3=Selva misionera}}\". Part of it has been transformed by mankind to implant cultures and ranching. The original biome is protected in [[Iguazú National Park]], part of the [[Alto Paraná Atlantic forests]], in turn part of the [[Atlantic Forest]] [[biome]].

column1: There are 1,101,593 people living in Misiones according to the national census of 2010. A part of the population is descendant of indigenous peoples (especially [[Guaranis]]) and also Spanish who reached during the colonization and mixed with natives. Another part of the residents are descendants of European [[Immigration to Argentina
column2: immigrants]]. Unlike many regions of Argentina, where the immigrants came through [[Buenos Aires]], most of the immigrants who settled in Misiones came through [[Southern Brazil]]. The ethnic groups who settled in Misiones after Spaniards are [[Italian people
column9: Danes]] and a small number of [[Arabs]], [[Japanese people
column10: Japanese]] and, recently, [[Laotians]] (in the late 1970s) and [[Chinese people
column11: Chinese]] (in the 2000s). From the 1960s, the province has also received immigrants from [[Brazil]] (mostly descendants of [[East Europeans]]) and [[Paraguay]] (mostly descendants both of indigenous peoples and Spaniards).

column1: [[Image:Aeropuerto Internacional de Puerto Iguazú PLANTA BAJA.JPG
column5: Terminal at [[Cataratas del Iguazú International Airport

column2: economy]], like most in northern Argentina, is relatively underdeveloped yet fairly well-diversified. Its 2006 output was estimated at US$4.8 billion (which shall be around US$7.2 billion in 2011, according to Argentina's economical growing) or US$4,940 per capita (around US$6,500 in 2011), over 40% below the national average.<ref>[http://www.iader.org.ar/ I.A.D.E.R<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

column1: Though its rainy, erosion-prone geography discourages [[intensive crop farming]], [[agriculture]] makes an important contribution to the province's economy, adding about 10% to the total. Misiones' thick forests have long provided for the ample production of roundwood without excessive impact on its [[ecosystem]]. The principal exploited trees are the [[Araucaria angustifolia
column2: Paraná pine]], Guatambú, Cedar, Petiribí, Incense, Cane water-pipe, Anchico, Eucalyptus and Gueycá.

column1: Misiones' chief source of agricultural income, however, has long been the cultivation of [[yerba mate]]: Misiones is Argentina's leading producer (yielding about half a million tons, annually).  [[Tea]], citrus fruit and, in minor amounts, [[tobacco]], sugar cane, rice, coffee, [[Cocoa bean
column2: cocoa]] and [[coconut]] are also cultivated in Misiones.{{Citation needed

column1: Light [[manufacturing]] and [[tourism]] also contribute to the local economy, each adding about 13% to the total.

The provincial government is divided into the usual three branches: the executive, headed by a popularly elected governor, who appoint the cabinet; the legislative; and the judiciary, headed by the Supreme Court.
The Constitution of Misiones Province forms the formal law of the province.
[[File:Bandera de ceremonias de la Unidad Regional IX (Jardín América) - Policía de Misiones.jpg
In Argentina, the most important law enforcement organization is the [[Argentine Federal Police]] but the additional work is carried out by the [[Misiones Provincial Police]].
The province is divided in 17 [[Departments of Argentina
*[http://www.misiones.gov.ar/ Gobierno de la Provincia de Misiones] Official website {{in lang

column1: Misiones is the second smallest province after [[Tucumán Province
[[File:Misiones - Parque provincial Salto Encantado desde ruta 7 (2).jpg

The Misiones plateau includes a part of Brazil across the border. The rocks contain significant quantities of iron which forms a part of the soil, giving it a reddish color. At the center of the plateau rises the Sierra de Misiones, its highest peak, 843 m, near Bernardo de Irigoyen, in the Cerro Rincón.
The province is embraced by three big rivers including the [[Paraná River
column4: Iguazú]]. [[Iguazu Falls]] are spectacular [[waterfall]]s on the Iguazú River in the northwest corner of the province, near the city of [[Puerto Iguazú]]. Misiones shares the falls with the Brazilian state of [[Paraná (state)
column5: Paraná]] (in that nation's Southern Region). Meanwhile, the international border with [[Paraguay]] is close by.

column1: The province has a [[humid subtropical climate]] characterized by a lack of a dry season and abundant rainfall throughout the year.<ref name=turismoclima>{{cite web
column8: accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> Under the [[Köppen climate classification]], it is classified as ''Cfa''.<ref name=IRNclima>{{cite web
column13: publisher=Secretaria de Mineria de la Nacion (Argentina)
column15: accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> There are four distinct seasons although winters and autumns are fairly short.<ref name=IRNclima/> The mean annual temperature is around {{convert
column19: 0}}.<ref name=turismoclima/> June–August typically register the coldest days when temperatures can fall below {{convert
column23: 0}}.<ref name=turismoclima/> However, rare incursions of polar air into the province from the south can lead to frost.<ref name=IRNclima/> Summers are hot with temperatures exceeding {{convert
column27: 0}} from December to February.<ref name=turismoclima/> One of the main characteristic is the presence of hills in the central and northern parts of the province leading to lower temperatures as a result of the higher elevation.<ref name=IRNclima/> Average annual rainfall ranges from a low of {{convert
column38: p=185}} The rainfall pattern in the province has a [[bimodal]] distribution with two peaks occurring in Spring and Autumn with winters being the driest.{{sfn
column41: p=185}} The exceptions are the north and higher altitude areas where precipitation is well distributed throughout the year.{{sfn
column44: p=185}} Snowfall has occurred at the higher hills.<ref name=IRNclima/> For example, during the winter of 1975, snowfall was observed and accumulated in Bernando de Irigoyen, one of the coldest towns in the province due to its high altitude {{convert
column48: abbr=on}}.<ref name=IRNclima/> Owing to the humid climate and high rainfall, relative humidity is high.<ref name=IRNclima/>

column1: The vegetation is the so-called \"{{Interlanguage link multi
column4: 3=Selva misionera}}\". Part of it has been transformed by mankind to implant cultures and ranching. The original biome is protected in [[Iguazú National Park]], part of the [[Alto Paraná Atlantic forests]], in turn part of the [[Atlantic Forest]] [[biome]].

column1: There are 1,101,593 people living in Misiones according to the national census of 2010. A part of the population is descendant of indigenous peoples (especially [[Guaranis]]) and also Spanish who reached during the colonization and mixed with natives. Another part of the residents are descendants of European [[Immigration to Argentina
column2: immigrants]]. Unlike many regions of Argentina, where the immigrants came through [[Buenos Aires]], most of the immigrants who settled in Misiones came through [[Southern Brazil]]. The ethnic groups who settled in Misiones after Spaniards are [[Italian people
column9: Danes]] and a small number of [[Arabs]], [[Japanese people
column10: Japanese]] and, recently, [[Laotians]] (in the late 1970s) and [[Chinese people
column11: Chinese]] (in the 2000s). From the 1960s, the province has also received immigrants from [[Brazil]] (mostly descendants of East Europeans) and [[Paraguay]] (mostly descendants both of indigenous peoples and Spaniards).

column1: [[Image:Aeropuerto Internacional de Puerto Iguazú PLANTA BAJA.JPG
column5: Terminal at [[Cataratas del Iguazú International Airport

column2: economy]], like most in northern Argentina, is relatively underdeveloped yet fairly well-diversified. Its 2006 output was estimated at US$4.8 billion (which shall be around US$7.2 billion in 2011, according to Argentina's economical growing) or US$4,940 per capita (around US$6,500 in 2011), over 40% below the national average.<ref>[http://www.iader.org.ar/ I.A.D.E.R<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

column1: Though its rainy, erosion-prone geography discourages [[intensive crop farming]], [[agriculture]] makes an important contribution to the province's economy, adding about 10% to the total. Misiones' thick forests have long provided for the ample production of roundwood without excessive impact on its [[ecosystem]]. The principal exploited trees are the [[Araucaria angustifolia
column2: Paraná pine]], Guatambú, Cedar, Petiribí, Incense, Cane water-pipe, Anchico, Eucalyptus and Gueycá.

column1: Misiones' chief source of agricultural income, however, has long been the cultivation of [[yerba mate]]: Misiones is Argentina's leading producer (yielding about half a million tons, annually).  [[Tea]], citrus fruit and, in minor amounts, [[tobacco]], sugar cane, rice, coffee, [[Cocoa bean
column2: cocoa]] and [[coconut]] are also cultivated in Misiones.{{Citation needed

column1: Light [[manufacturing]] and [[tourism]] also contribute to the local economy, each adding about 13% to the total.

The provincial government is divided into the usual three branches: the executive, headed by a popularly elected governor, who appoint the cabinet; the legislative; and the judiciary, headed by the Supreme Court.
The Constitution of Misiones Province forms the formal law of the province.
[[File:Bandera de ceremonias de la Unidad Regional IX (Jardín América) - Policía de Misiones.jpg
In Argentina, the most important law enforcement organization is the [[Argentine Federal Police]] but the additional work is carried out by the [[Misiones Provincial Police]].
The province is divided in 17 [[Departments of Argentina
*[http://www.misiones.gov.ar/ Gobierno de la Provincia de Misiones] Official website {{in lang
