column2: Details of ongoing viral pandemic on USS Theodore Roosevelt (CVN-71)}}
name            = 2020 coronavirus pandemic on board USS ''Theodore Roosevelt''

arrival_date = 24 March 2020
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days

column5: title=585 COVID-19 Cases Among USS Theodore Roosevelt Crew, Navy Says

column1: The [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]] was detected on the aircraft carrier {{USS
column4: 6}} in March 2020 while she was at sea. Affected crew members were evacuated and the ship was ordered to Guam. The captain, [[Brett Crozier]], wanted most of the sailors to be removed from the ship to prevent the spread of the disease, but his superiors balked. After several days he emailed multiple Navy officers begging for the ship to be largely evacuated because the virus could not be contained on board ship. The letter leaked to the press, and the next day the Navy ordered most of the crew to be taken ashore, but the captain was relieved of command by Acting Secretary of the Navy [[Thomas Modly]]. Modly's order, and his later speech to the crew aboard the ''Roosevelt'', were controversial and he resigned a few days later. By mid April hundreds of crew members including Crozier had tested positive for the virus, and one had died.

column1: In spring 2020 the [[United States Navy]] aircraft carrier {{USS
column4: 2}} was on deployment in the Pacific.

column1: On 5 March the ship made a four-day-long port call at [[Da Nang]], Vietnam. On the last night some sailors stayed at a hotel where two people had tested positive for [[COVID-19]], a coronavirus disease identified as the cause of an outbreak of respiratory illness. Upon learning this, the crew were ordered back to the ship and the sailors who had stayed at the hotel were isolated. Over the next weeks the ship's medical team monitored the crew for any signs of infection.<ref name = losses/>
On 24 March it was reported that three sailors aboard had tested positive for the virus.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Three sailors from USS Theodore Roosevelt have coronavirus, raising concerns about pandemic's strain on military

column1: Within a few days, that number climbed to \"dozens.\" ''Theodore Roosevelt'' was ordered to [[Guam]] and docked on 27 March 2020.<ref name= disinfectUssTRcvn71 />
On 30 March, the ship's commanding officer, Captain [[Brett Crozier]], sent an [[Classified information in the United States#Unclassified
column2: unclassified email]] to multiple Navy officials asking for help with the coronavirus epidemic on his ship. He sent copies of the email to \"20 or 30\" people, including members of his staff and others not in his chain of command.<ref name = Cohn>{{Cite news
column6: title=This is what was so unusual about the U.S. Navy making Captain Brett Crozier step down—Members of the military can face multiple, sometimes competing, loyalties
column12: first3=Jim}}</ref> According to a Navy officer, the letter didn't conform to Navy standards.<ref name=realclear>{{cite web

column1: On 31 March, over 100 sailors tested positive.<ref name=Schogol>{{cite web
column4: title=Navy captain says COVID-19 is spreading through his aircraft carrier so rapidly that most of the crew needs to get off
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> The letter was leaked to the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]],'' which published it.<ref name = Gafni>{{cite news
column13: title=Exclusive: Captain of aircraft carrier with growing coronavirus outbreak pleads for help from Navy

column1: On 1 April, the Navy ordered the aircraft carrier largely evacuated, with a skeleton crew to remain aboard the vessel to maintain the nuclear reactor, the fire-fighting equipment, the ship's galley, and a disenfection crew.<ref name= disinfectUssTRcvn71 >{{cite news
column5: title=US Navy Evacuating Aircraft Carrier Infected by Coronavirus

column1: On 2 April, acting [[United States Secretary of the Navy
column2: Navy Secretary]] [[Thomas Modly]] relieved Crozier of his command.<ref name=\"NBC Crozier Relieved\">{{cite news
column7: title=Navy relieves captain who raised alarm about coronavirus outbreak on aircraft carrier
column11: date=2 April 2020}}</ref> According to Modly, Crozier didn't inform his [[Carrier Strike Group 9
column12: superior on the ship]] about sending the letter, and Modly conferred with Crozier's [[chain of command]].<ref name=Gallagher>{{cite web
column15: title=Aircraft carrier captain lost his command because of “Catch-22” COVID-19 dilemma

column1: On 5 April 2020, the Navy confirmed that 155 sailors had been infected and that 1,500 sailors had been removed from the ship, a lower number than the Navy had projected several days earlier.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=155 sailors on USS Theodore Roosevelt test positive for coronavirus, 42 percent of all Navy infections

column1: On 6 April Modly traveled to Guam to visit the ship in person.<ref name=\"trip\">{{cite news
column6: page=A11}}</ref> He made a speech to the crew over the ship's [[public address system]], strongly criticizing Crozier. The transcript and an audio recording of Modly's speech were subsequently leaked to the media.<ref name = Larison/> Later that day, Modly apologized for the comment.<ref name = Casiano>{{cite news
column8: title=Trump hints that he may get involved in Navy episode as Modly issues apology
column15: accessdate=7 April 2020}}</ref> He resigned from his post the following day.

column1: On 7 April, the Navy said 61% of ''Theodore Roosevelt''{{'}}s crew had been tested for COVID-19 and 173 members had tested positive, including Captain Crozier. None were hospitalized. Two thousand sailors — just under half the total crew — had been moved ashore.<ref name=\"Guardian20200407\">{{cite news
column6: title=US navy official apologises for calling captain behind coronavirus memo 'naive or stupid'

column1: On 8 April the Navy reported that 416 crew members had tested positive for the virus, and that one quarantined sailor was hospitalized in intensive care after being found unconscious in his quarantine quarters.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=A USS Theodore Roosevelt sailor with coronavirus was taken to the ICU as the number of cases on the aircraft carrier rises

column1: On 11 April it was reported that more than 90% of the crew hd been tested for the coronavirus, and 550 crew members had tested positive.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=100 more sailors from the USS Theodore Roosevelt have tested positive for coronavirus, making up 75% of the Navy's total cases worldwide
column11: title=Coronavirus cases on USS Theodore Roosevelt spike to 550

column1: As of 12 April, 585 crew members had tested positive. <ref name = dies/>

On 13 April, the hospitalized sailor died.<ref name = dies>politico.com: [https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/13/sailor-uss-roosevelt-dies-coronavirus-183164 ''Sailor from USS Theodore Roosevelt dies of coronavirus'']</ref>

When the ship arrived in Guam on 26 March the ship's commanding officer, Captain [[Brett Crozier]], wanted to have most of the crew immediately taken ashore, saying it was impossible to prevent the spread of the virus in the close quarters of the ship. His superior, Rear Adm. [[Stuart P. Baker]], disagreed, feeling such an action was impractical and too drastic.<ref name = losses>{{cite news
column3: title=‘There Will Be Losses’: How a Captain’s Plea Exposed a Rift in the Military

column1: On 30 March, Crozier sent an email to communicate the status of his ship and its crew, saying it was not possible to observe [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column3: title=Restriction of Movement (ROM) guidance. Navy mitigation measures in response to Novel Coronavirus outbreak
column6: date=11 March 2020}}</ref> recommendations for individual quarantine or [[social distancing]] aboard the carrier. Crozier referred to the [[2020 coronavirus pandemic on Diamond Princess
column7: viral spread on the less crowded cruise ship ''Diamond Princess'']] as an example of [[Basic reproduction number
column8: how quickly a virus can spread]] on a crowded vessel.<ref name = Gafni/><ref name=\"documentcloud\">{{cite web
column11: title=Request for assistance in response to COVID-19 pandemic
column13: title=Request of assistance in response to pandemic on USS Theodore Roosevelt, by Captain Brett E. Crozier (text)
column17: date=30 March 2020}}</ref> The letter provided his superiors with options, but recommended most<!--90%--> of the crew's evacuation, keeping only enough crew on board to maintain the nuclear reactor, provide security, and to [[Disinfection
column18: sanitize the ship]]. He sent copies of the email to \"20 or 30\" people, including members of his staff and others not in his chain of command, but not including Admiral Baker.<ref name = Cohn/><ref name = losses/> The letter was leaked to the ''San Francisco Chronicle'', which published it the next day.<ref name = Gafni/>

column1: On 2 April, acting [[United States Secretary of the Navy
column2: Navy Secretary]] [[Thomas Modly]] relieved Crozier of his command for sending the request for assistance over non-secure email to a \"broad array of people\" rather than up the chain of command, adding that Crozier \"allowed the complexity of the challenge of the COVID breakout on the ship to overwhelm his ability to act professionally\". Crozier will remain in the Navy and retain his rank.<ref name=\"NBC Crozier Relieved\">{{cite news
column7: title=Navy relieves captain who raised alarm about coronavirus outbreak on aircraft carrier
column11: date=2 April 2020}}</ref> As Crozier disembarked, sailors were seen chanting \"Cap-tain Cro-zier\" in a video posted to [[Twitter]] captioned \"Wrongfully relieved of command but did right by the sailors.\"<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Videos show sailors cheering Navy captain relieved of command after raising alarm on coronavirus

column3: video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?470922-1/us-navy-fires-captain-raised-alarm-coronavirus-aircraft-carrier U.S. Department of Defense briefing with Navy Secretary Modly in which he announces the relief of Capt. Crozier from his duty as the captain of the ''Theodore Roosevelt'', April 2, 2020], [[C-SPAN]]}}

column1: Reaction to Crozier's dismissal was mixed. A ''Wall Street Journal'' story reported that on \"Capitol Hill and inside the Pentagon, lawmakers and officials reacted with confusion and anger over the dismissal\" of Crozier.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Captain Fired by Navy Gets Rousing Farewell from Sailors
column9: publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}}</ref> A joint statement from four Democrats on the [[United States House Committee on Armed Services
column10: House Armed Services Committee]], including the committee chair, [[Adam Smith (politician)
column11: Representative Adam Smith (D-WA)]], criticized Crozier's conduct, saying that \"Captain Crozier was justifiably concerned about the health and safety of his crew, but he did not handle the immense pressure appropriately. However, relieving him of his command is an overreaction.\"<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=After Outcry Over Navy Captain Relieved Of Command, Assurances He Won't Be Expelled
column18: President Trump]] also criticized Crozier's letter on 4 April saying that it was \"not appropriate.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column20: title=Trump says Navy captain letter asking for help on coronavirus-stricken ship 'was terrible'

column1: Modly, U.S. Defense Secretary [[Mark Esper]], and Chief of Naval Operations Admiral [[Michael M. Gilday
column2: Michael Gilday]] each defended the decision to remove Crozier.<ref name=croziergone>{{cite web
column5: title=Aircraft carrier captain removed from duty after pleading for help with coronavirus outbreak
column13: title=Esper defends removing USS Theodore Roosevelt commander who sounded alarm over coronavirus
column17: accessdate=2020-04-06}}</ref> Modly added that there was no White House pressure when the decision was made to remove Crozier.<ref name=croziergone />

column3: mi}}<ref name=\"trip\"/> to Guam on a Navy executive jet; the trip was later reported to have cost taxpayers at least $243,000.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Trip to Guam at center of top Navy official’s resignation cost taxpayers over $243,000
column10: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref> He visited the ship in person and made a speech to the crew over the ship's [[public address system]]. He began by blaming the Chinese government for worsening the outbreak by not telling how bad the disease was. He continued by strongly criticizing Crozier, saying he was \"too naïve or too stupid to be a commanding officer,\" if he did not realize that the letter would be leaked to the media.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=Acting Navy Secretary Slams Fired Captain as 'Stupid'
column19: accessdate=6 April 2020}}</ref> Modly also scolded the ship's crew for cheering their captain as he left.<ref name=\"trip\"/>  The transcript and an audio recording of Modly's speech was subsequently leaked to the media.<ref name = Larison>{{cite news
column22: title=After Crozier Comments, Navy Secretary Modly Must Resign

column1: Modly's speech was widely criticized. [[United States Senate
column2: Senator]] [[Tim Kaine]] stated \"It's deeply disappointing that he would deliver a speech on board a U.S. aircraft carrier suggesting that Captain Crozier might be 'stupid'.\" [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives
column3: House Speaker]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] and [[United States House of Representatives
column4: Representative]] [[Elaine Luria]] called for the removal of Modly, with Luria, a Navy veteran, saying he was \"in no way fit\" to lead the Navy.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=U.S. Navy morale dives after firing of virus-riddled ship's captain
column9: language=en}}</ref> Chairperson of the [[United States House Armed Services Subcommittee on Military Personnel
column10: Armed Services Committee's panel on military personnel]], [[United States House of Representatives
column11: Representative]] [[Jackie Speier]] also criticized the trip.<ref name=\"ModlyCost\">{{cite news
column14: title=Cost of Navy secretary's trip to Guam? $243,000, his job and isolation after coronavirus exposure

column1: On 6 April, Modly apologized for the comment.<ref name = Casiano/> The following day, he resigned his position.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Acting Navy Secretary Thomas Modly Resigns in Wake of USS Roosevelt Comments

column1: On April 13, the first fatality among the sailors on board the ship was announced.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-13/navy-sailor-from-uss-theodore-roosevelt-died-of-covid-19 \"Navy Sailor Dies in Guam After Virus Outbreak Aboard Carrier\"] Bloomberg.com</ref>

column2: x= 23 Mar, 24 Mar, 25 Mar, 26 Mar, 27 Mar, 28 Mar, 29 Mar, 30 Mar, 31 Mar, 1 Apr, 2 Apr, 3 Apr, 4 Apr, 5 Apr, 6 Apr, 7 Apr, 8 Apr, 9 Apr, 10 Apr, 11 Apr, 12 Apr

column20: title=Trump says Navy captain letter asking for help on coronavirus-stricken ship 'was terrible'

column1: Modly, U.S. Defense Secretary [[Mark Esper]], and Chief of Naval Operations Admiral [[Michael M. Gilday
column2: Michael Gilday]] each defended the decision to remove Crozier.<ref name=croziergone>{{cite web
column5: title=Aircraft carrier captain removed from duty after pleading for help with coronavirus outbreak
column13: title=Esper defends removing USS Theodore Roosevelt commander who sounded alarm over coronavirus
column17: accessdate=2020-04-06}}</ref> Modly added that there was no White House pressure when the decision was made to remove Crozier.<ref name=croziergone />

column3: mi}}<ref name=\"trip\"/> to Guam on a Navy executive jet; the trip was later reported to have cost taxpayers at least $243,000.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Trip to Guam at center of top Navy official’s resignation cost taxpayers over $243,000
column10: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref> He visited the ship in person and made a speech to the crew over the ship's [[public address system]]. He began by blaming the Chinese government for worsening the outbreak by not telling how bad the disease was. He continued by strongly criticizing Crozier, saying he was \"too naïve or too stupid to be a commanding officer,\" if he did not realize that the letter would be leaked to the media.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=Acting Navy Secretary Slams Fired Captain as 'Stupid'
column19: accessdate=6 April 2020}}</ref> Modly also scolded the ship's crew for cheering their captain as he left.<ref name=\"trip\"/>  The transcript and an audio recording of Modly's speech was subsequently leaked to the media.<ref name = Larison>{{cite news
column22: title=After Crozier Comments, Navy Secretary Modly Must Resign

column1: Modly's speech was widely criticized. [[United States Senate
column2: Senator]] [[Tim Kaine]] stated \"It's deeply disappointing that he would deliver a speech on board a U.S. aircraft carrier suggesting that Captain Crozier might be 'stupid'.\" [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives
column3: House Speaker]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] and [[United States House of Representatives
column4: Representative]] [[Elaine Luria]] called for the removal of Modly, with Luria, a Navy veteran, saying he was \"in no way fit\" to lead the Navy.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=U.S. Navy morale dives after firing of virus-riddled ship's captain
column9: language=en}}</ref> Chairperson of the [[United States House Armed Services Subcommittee on Military Personnel
column10: Armed Services Committee's panel on military personnel]], [[United States House of Representatives
column11: Representative]] [[Jackie Speier]] also criticized the trip.<ref name=\"ModlyCost\">{{cite news
column14: title=Cost of Navy secretary's trip to Guam? $243,000, his job and isolation after coronavirus exposure

column1: On 6 April, Modly apologized for the comment.<ref name = Casiano/> The following day, he resigned his position.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Acting Navy Secretary Thomas Modly Resigns in Wake of USS Roosevelt Comments

column1: On April 13, the first fatality among the sailors on board the ship was announced.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-13/navy-sailor-from-uss-theodore-roosevelt-died-of-covid-19 \"Navy Sailor Dies in Guam After Virus Outbreak Aboard Carrier\"] Bloomberg.com</ref>

column1: *[[2020 coronavirus pandemic in the United States]]
{{2020 coronavirus pandemic in the United States}}
[[Category:2020 coronavirus pandemic in the United States
[[Category:Aircraft carriers involved in the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic
[[Category:Military controversies]]",2020 coronavirus pandemic on USS Theodore Roosevelt (CVN-71),//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_coronavirus_pandemic_on_USS_Theodore_Roosevelt_(CVN-71)

column2: Details of ongoing viral pandemic on USS Theodore Roosevelt (CVN-71)}}
name            = 2020 coronavirus pandemic on board USS ''Theodore Roosevelt''

arrival_date = 24 March 2020
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days

column5: title=585 COVID-19 Cases Among USS Theodore Roosevelt Crew, Navy Says

column1: The [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]] was detected on the aircraft carrier {{USS
column4: 6}} in March 2020 while she was at sea. Affected crew members were evacuated and the ship was ordered to Guam. The captain, [[Brett Crozier]], wanted most of the sailors to be removed from the ship to prevent the spread of the disease, but his superiors balked. After several days he emailed multiple Navy officers begging for the ship to be largely evacuated because the virus could not be contained on board ship. The letter leaked to the press, and the next day the Navy ordered most of the crew to be taken ashore, but the captain was relieved of command by Acting Secretary of the Navy [[Thomas Modly]]. Modly's order, and his later speech to the crew aboard the ''Roosevelt'', were controversial and he resigned a few days later. By mid-April hundreds of crew members including Crozier had tested positive for the virus, and one had died.

column1: In spring 2020, the [[United States Navy]] aircraft carrier {{USS
column4: 2}} was on deployment in the Pacific.

column1: On 5 March, the ship made a four-day-long port call at [[Da Nang]], Vietnam. On the last night some sailors stayed at a hotel where two people had tested positive for [[COVID-19]], a coronavirus disease identified as the cause of an outbreak of respiratory illness. Upon learning this, the crew were ordered back to the ship and the sailors who had stayed at the hotel were isolated. Over the next weeks the ship's medical team monitored the crew for any signs of infection.<ref name = losses/>
On 24 March, it was reported that three sailors aboard had tested positive for the virus.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Three sailors from USS Theodore Roosevelt have coronavirus, raising concerns about pandemic's strain on military

column1: Within a few days, that number climbed to \"dozens.\" ''Theodore Roosevelt'' was ordered to [[Guam]] and docked on 27 March 2020.<ref name= disinfectUssTRcvn71 />
On 30 March, the ship's commanding officer, Captain [[Brett Crozier]], sent an [[Classified information in the United States#Unclassified
column2: unclassified email]] to multiple Navy officials asking for help with the coronavirus epidemic on his ship. He sent copies of the email to \"20 or 30\" people, including members of his staff and others not in his chain of command.<ref name = Cohn>{{Cite news
column6: title=This is what was so unusual about the U.S. Navy making Captain Brett Crozier step down—Members of the military can face multiple, sometimes competing, loyalties
column12: first3=Jim}}</ref> According to a Navy officer, the letter didn't conform to Navy standards.<ref name=realclear>{{cite web

column1: On 31 March, over 100 sailors tested positive.<ref name=Schogol>{{cite web
column4: title=Navy captain says COVID-19 is spreading through his aircraft carrier so rapidly that most of the crew needs to get off
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> The letter was leaked to the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]],'' which published it.<ref name = Gafni>{{cite news
column13: title=Exclusive: Captain of aircraft carrier with growing coronavirus outbreak pleads for help from Navy

column1: On 1 April, the Navy ordered the aircraft carrier largely evacuated, with a skeleton crew to remain aboard the vessel to maintain the nuclear reactor, the fire-fighting equipment, the ship's galley, and a disenfection crew.<ref name= disinfectUssTRcvn71 >{{cite news
column5: title=US Navy Evacuating Aircraft Carrier Infected by Coronavirus

column1: On 2 April, acting [[United States Secretary of the Navy
column2: Navy Secretary]] [[Thomas Modly]] relieved Crozier of his command.<ref name=\"NBC Crozier Relieved\">{{cite news
column7: title=Navy relieves captain who raised alarm about coronavirus outbreak on aircraft carrier
column11: date=2 April 2020}}</ref> According to Modly, Crozier didn't inform his [[Carrier Strike Group 9
column12: superior on the ship]] about sending the letter, and Modly conferred with Crozier's [[chain of command]].<ref name=Gallagher>{{cite web
column15: title=Aircraft carrier captain lost his command because of “Catch-22” COVID-19 dilemma

column1: On 5 April 2020, the Navy confirmed that 155 sailors had been infected and that 1,500 sailors had been removed from the ship, a lower number than the Navy had projected several days earlier.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=155 sailors on USS Theodore Roosevelt test positive for coronavirus, 42 percent of all Navy infections

column1: On 6 April, Modly traveled to Guam to visit the ship in person.<ref name=\"trip\">{{cite news
column6: page=A11}}</ref> He made a speech to the crew over the ship's [[public address system]], strongly criticizing Crozier. The transcript and an audio recording of Modly's speech were subsequently leaked to the media.<ref name = Larison/> Later that day, Modly apologized for the comment.<ref name = Casiano>{{cite news
column8: title=Trump hints that he may get involved in Navy episode as Modly issues apology
column15: accessdate=7 April 2020}}</ref> He resigned from his post the following day.

column1: On 7 April, the Navy said 61% of ''Theodore Roosevelt''{{'}}s crew had been tested for COVID-19 and 173 members had tested positive, including Captain Crozier. None were hospitalized. Two thousand sailors — just under half the total crew — had been moved ashore.<ref name=\"Guardian20200407\">{{cite news
column6: title=US navy official apologises for calling captain behind coronavirus memo 'naive or stupid'

column1: On 8 April the Navy reported that 416 crew members had tested positive for the virus, and that one quarantined sailor was hospitalized in intensive care after being found unconscious in his quarantine quarters.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=A USS Theodore Roosevelt sailor with coronavirus was taken to the ICU as the number of cases on the aircraft carrier rises

column1: On 11 April, it was reported that more than 90% of the crew hd been tested for the coronavirus, and 550 crew members had tested positive.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=100 more sailors from the USS Theodore Roosevelt have tested positive for coronavirus, making up 75% of the Navy's total cases worldwide
column11: title=Coronavirus cases on USS Theodore Roosevelt spike to 550

column1: As of 12 April, 585 crew members had tested positive. <ref name = dies/>

On 13 April, the hospitalized sailor died.<ref name = dies>politico.com: [https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/13/sailor-uss-roosevelt-dies-coronavirus-183164 ''Sailor from USS Theodore Roosevelt dies of coronavirus'']</ref>

When the ship arrived in Guam on 26 March the ship's commanding officer, Captain [[Brett Crozier]], wanted to have most of the crew immediately taken ashore, saying it was impossible to prevent the spread of the virus in the close quarters of the ship. His superior, Rear Adm. [[Stuart P. Baker]], disagreed, feeling such an action was impractical and too drastic.<ref name = losses>{{cite news
column3: title=‘There Will Be Losses’: How a Captain’s Plea Exposed a Rift in the Military

column1: On 30 March, Crozier sent an email to communicate the status of his ship and its crew, saying it was not possible to observe [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column3: title=Restriction of Movement (ROM) guidance. Navy mitigation measures in response to Novel Coronavirus outbreak
column6: date=11 March 2020}}</ref> recommendations for individual quarantine or [[social distancing]] aboard the carrier. Crozier referred to the [[2020 coronavirus pandemic on Diamond Princess
column7: viral spread on the less crowded cruise ship ''Diamond Princess'']] as an example of [[Basic reproduction number
column8: how quickly a virus can spread]] on a crowded vessel.<ref name = Gafni/><ref name=\"documentcloud\">{{cite web
column11: title=Request for assistance in response to COVID-19 pandemic
column13: title=Request of assistance in response to pandemic on USS Theodore Roosevelt, by Captain Brett E. Crozier (text)
column17: date=30 March 2020}}</ref> The letter provided his superiors with options, but recommended most<!--90%--> of the crew's evacuation, keeping only enough crew on board to maintain the nuclear reactor, provide security, and to [[Disinfection
column18: sanitize the ship]]. He sent copies of the email to \"20 or 30\" people, including members of his staff and others not in his chain of command, but not including Admiral Baker.<ref name = Cohn/><ref name = losses/> The letter was leaked to the ''San Francisco Chronicle'', which published it the next day.<ref name = Gafni/>

column1: On 2 April, acting [[United States Secretary of the Navy
column2: Navy Secretary]] [[Thomas Modly]] relieved Crozier of his command for sending the request for assistance over non-secure email to a \"broad array of people\" rather than up the chain of command, adding that Crozier \"allowed the complexity of the challenge of the COVID breakout on the ship to overwhelm his ability to act professionally\". Crozier will remain in the Navy and retain his rank.<ref name=\"NBC Crozier Relieved\">{{cite news
column7: title=Navy relieves captain who raised alarm about coronavirus outbreak on aircraft carrier
column11: date=2 April 2020}}</ref> As Crozier disembarked, sailors were seen chanting \"Cap-tain Cro-zier\" in a video posted to [[Twitter]] captioned \"Wrongfully relieved of command but did right by the sailors.\"<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Videos show sailors cheering Navy captain relieved of command after raising alarm on coronavirus

column3: video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?470922-1/us-navy-fires-captain-raised-alarm-coronavirus-aircraft-carrier U.S. Department of Defense briefing with Navy Secretary Modly in which he announces the relief of Capt. Crozier from his duty as the captain of the ''Theodore Roosevelt'', April 2, 2020], [[C-SPAN]]}}

column1: Reaction to Crozier's dismissal was mixed. A ''Wall Street Journal'' story reported that on \"Capitol Hill and inside the Pentagon, lawmakers and officials reacted with confusion and anger over the dismissal\" of Crozier.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Captain Fired by Navy Gets Rousing Farewell from Sailors
column9: publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}}</ref> A joint statement from four Democrats on the [[United States House Committee on Armed Services
column10: House Armed Services Committee]], including the committee chair, [[Adam Smith (politician)
column11: Representative Adam Smith (D-WA)]], criticized Crozier's conduct, saying that \"Captain Crozier was justifiably concerned about the health and safety of his crew, but he did not handle the immense pressure appropriately. However, relieving him of his command is an overreaction.\"<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=After Outcry Over Navy Captain Relieved Of Command, Assurances He Won't Be Expelled
column18: President Trump]] also criticized Crozier's letter on 4 April saying that it was \"not appropriate.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column20: title=Trump says Navy captain letter asking for help on coronavirus-stricken ship 'was terrible'

column1: Modly, U.S. Defense Secretary [[Mark Esper]], and Chief of Naval Operations Admiral [[Michael M. Gilday
column2: Michael Gilday]] each defended the decision to remove Crozier.<ref name=croziergone>{{cite web
column5: title=Aircraft carrier captain removed from duty after pleading for help with coronavirus outbreak
column13: title=Esper defends removing USS Theodore Roosevelt commander who sounded alarm over coronavirus
column17: accessdate=2020-04-06}}</ref> Modly added that there was no White House pressure when the decision was made to remove Crozier.<ref name=croziergone />

column4: Representative]] [[Elaine Luria]] called for the removal of Modly, with Luria, a Navy veteran, saying he was \"in no way fit\" to lead the Navy.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=U.S. Navy morale dives after firing of virus-riddled ship's captain
column9: language=en}}</ref> Chairperson of the [[United States House Armed Services Subcommittee on Military Personnel
column10: Armed Services Committee's panel on military personnel]], [[United States House of Representatives
column11: Representative]] [[Jackie Speier]] also criticized the trip.<ref name=\"ModlyCost\">{{cite news
column14: title=Cost of Navy secretary's trip to Guam? $243,000, his job and isolation after coronavirus exposure

column1: \"'''Break My Heart'''\" is a song by English singer [[Dua Lipa]]. It was released on 25 March 2020 through [[Warner Records]] as the third single from her second studio album ''[[Future Nostalgia (Dua Lipa album)
column4: title=Another Banger? Dua Lipa Teases New Single \"Break My Heart\"
column10: title=Dua Lipa's single 'Break My Heart' from upcoming album 'Future Nostalgia' features a sample by rock band INXS
column12: accessdate=2020-03-20}}</ref> and impacted [[contemporary hit radio]] on 31 March as the second US single off the album.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: AllAccess]]}}</ref> The song was written by Lipa, [[Ali Tamposi
column18: Alexandra Tamposi]] and its producers [[the Monsters & Strangerz]]. \"Break My Heart\" samples the melody from \"[[Need You Tonight]]\" (1987) by [[INXS]], thus [[Michael Hutchence]] and [[Andrew Farriss]] are also credited as songwriters.<ref name=\"Sample\" />

column1: \"Break My Heart\" was leaked in January 2020 along with \"[[Physical (Dua Lipa song)
column2: Physical]].\"<ref name=\"Sample\" /> Lipa first revealed that the song would serve as the third single from ''Future Nostalgia'' in March 2020 on the Australian TV show ''[[Sunrise (Australian TV program)
column5: title=Another Banger? Dua Lipa Teases New Single \"Break My Heart\"
column8: accessdate=2020-03-20}}</ref> Lipa revealed the cover art and announced that the song would be released on 27 March 2020.<ref>{{Cite tweet
column17: title=Dua Lipa divulga capa e data de lançamento de \"Break My Heart\"
column20: access-date=2020-03-20}}</ref> She later pushed up the release of the song to 25 March 2020 due to ''a'' potential and full leak of the album.<ref>{{Cite web
column22: title=Dua Lipa Emotionally Announces 'Future Nostalgia' Has A New Earlier Release Date

column1: Lipa said that she sees the song as a \"celebration of vulnerability and being open about the vulnerable side of being in love, where I previously saw as weakness.<ref name = \"Livestream\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Dua Lipa - Future Nostalgia Livestream PART 2 - #StayHome #WithMe

column1: Musically, \"Break My Heart\" is a three minute and forty-one second [[dance-pop]]<ref>{{Cite web

column10: title=Dua Lipa Continues Her Disco-Pop Hot Streak With New Song 'Break My Heart'
column17: title=Dua Lipa Shares New Single 'Break My Heart'
column21: title=Dua Lipa's vivid, disco-infused 'Future Nostalgia' is an instant pop classic
column28: accessdate=11 April 2020}}</ref> song with a [[europop]] beat<ref>{{Citeweb
column30: title=Social distancing could have saved Dua Lipa from angst in the video for \"Break My Heart\"
column35: accessdate=29 March 2020}}}</ref> in a \"retro-futuristic\" style.<ref name=\"MTV\">{{Cite web
column37: title=Dua Lipa Continues Her Disco-Pop Hot Streak With New Song 'Break My Heart'
column42: accessdate=26 March 2020}}</ref> It features bouncing-ball bass, handclaps<ref>{{Cite web
column44: title=Dua Lipa offers up high-octane pop bliss on Future Nostalgia
column49: accessdate=27 March 2020}}</ref>, a staccato bass rhythm<ref>{{Cite web
column51: title=Dua Lipa's \"Future Nostalgia\" Is Dance Pop for When the Sky Is Falling
column56: accessdate=27 March 2020}}</ref> and an \"uplifting retro-inspired dance beat\".<ref>{{Cite web
column58: title=Dua Lipa's New Break My Heart Music Video Will Have You Dancing Out of Your Seat
column63: accessdate=27 March 2020}}</ref> The song interpolates the melody from \"[[Need You Tonight]]\" by [[INXS]].<ref name=\"slantmagazine\">{{Cite web
column65: title=Review: Dua Lipa's Future Nostalgia Is a Euphoric Escape Hatch to Pop's Past
column70: accessdate=25 March 2020}}</ref> Lyrically, the song is about being unable to resist the temptation of pursuing love.<ref>{{Cite web

column2: music notation]], \"Break My Heart\" was composed using [[Time signature
column6: key]] of [[E minor]], with a [[tempo]] of 113 [[beats per minute]].<ref name=\"Musicnotes\">{{Cite web
column8: title=Dua Lipa \"Break My Heart\" Sheet Music in E Minor
column17: accessdate=27 March 2020}}</ref> Lipa's vocal range spans from the low note E3 to the high note of B4.<ref name=\"Musicnotes\" />

column1: The song's accompanying music video premiered via [[YouTube
column2: YouTube premiere]] on 26 March 2020 and was directed by Henry Scholfield.<ref name = \"YouTube\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Dua Lipa - Break My Heart (Official Video)
column14: title=Dua Lipa Releases New Single 'Break My Heart' — Check Out the Upbeat Music Video
column21: accessdate=2020-03-27}}</ref> The video was shot in [[Sofia
column22: Sofia, Bulgaria]] in January 2020 over the course of five days.<ref>{{Cite web
column24: title=JAVIER ALEJANDRO on Instagram: “@dualipa video 🔫🍭 another one with the Hermano Scholfield. @hscholfield 🦾 Love to the production Queens who always keep me in Line and on…”
column28: title=LOUIS MCMILLER on Instagram: “💔 BREAK MY HEART 💔 @dualipa ✨ -8 degrees mixed with 5 days of constant laughing and bopping 🥶🤣 A fab team all round and this is what we got…”
column32: title=🤤 on Instagram: “Protect your local popstars! Especially those with flu in -8°C in Bulgaria in January! Love you Dua💔 🎀BREAK MY HEART VIDEO OUT NOW🎀”
column34: accessdate=28 March 2020}}</ref> The video features a set of \"’90s-inspired slide clips.\"<ref>{{Citeweb
column36: title=Dua Lipa’s New ‘Break My Heart’ Music Video Makes the Case for Growing Out Your Roots

column1: The video begins with Lipa jumping on cars and walking through a traffic-jammed city block.<ref name = \"popsugar\">{{Citeweb
column3: title=Dua Lipa Released a Groovy Music Video, and TikTok Must Be Scrambling to Learn the Dance
column8: accessdate=29 March 2020}}</ref> She is then seen in a man's apartment where she struggles to maintain her balance.<ref name = \"MTV video\">{{Citeweb
column10: title=DUA LIPA RIDES A HAMSTER WHEEL OF HEARTBREAK IN VIBRANT NEW VIDEO
column15: accessdate=29 March 2020}}</ref> This is a metaphor for being uncertain about whether her feelings are being reciprocated.<ref name = \"MTV video\"/> Lipa then finds herself in a restaurant where she observes various couples going through issues.<ref name = \"People\"/> She starts to dance on a disco floor in the middle of the restaurant before a wall explodes and she is sucked out.<ref name = \"popsugar\"/><ref name = \"MTV video\"/> She lands on an airplane seat where she gets up and walks to the back before it breaks off.<ref name = \"People\"/> The carpet used on the plane is that of ''[[The Shining (film)
column16: The Shining]]'' (1980).<ref name = \"popsugar\"/> Lipa then begins to dance on the end of the plane before a life raft explodes on her and she wakes up in a bed with a confused partner.<ref name = \"People\"/> She runs scared into the bathroom picking up her shoes and beds with other men begin cycling through in the background.<ref name = \"People\"/> She then falls into the bathtub which turns into a frothy pink martini one of Lipa's backup dancers is holding while she dances on a bar couch.<ref name = \"MTV video\"/> The video concludes looking at all the previous scenes and undoing some of the transitions before Lipa blows a bubble sitting on a car from the first scene.<ref name = \"YouTube\"/>

column4: Germany]] and [[Japan women's national football team
column5: Japan]]. It began on 20 September and its last matches were played on 27 September. Most matches were played at the [[Columbus Crew Stadium]] in [[Columbus, Ohio
column6: Columbus]]. Germany won every match, while Argentina failed to win a match. Despite beating Argentina 6–0, Japan failed to advance, while a young Canada team surprisingly made the second round.

column2: partof      = the [[Burma Campaign]] of the [[World War II
caption     = Brigadier Mike Calvert (left) gives orders to Lieutenant-Colonel Shaw, with (right) Major James Lumley after the capture of Mogaung.

column1: The '''Battle of Mogaung''' was a series of engagements that was fought in the [[Burma Campaign]] of [[World War II]] between 6 to 26 June 1944 at the Burmese town of Mogaung. In brutal fighting, the [[77th Indian Infantry Brigade
column3: Michael Calvert]], later assisted by [[Chinese Expeditionary Force
column4: Chinese forces]] of Generalissimo [[Chiang Kai-shek]], fought-for and captured the town from the [[Japanese occupation of Burma

column1: The battle was part of a major [[Chindit]] campaign called [[Chindits#Operation Thursday
column2: Operation ''Thursday'']] which later amalgamated with the [[Siege of Myitkyina]] by Chinese and US forces led by [[Joseph Stilwell]] who was in overall command of the Chindits. The capture of Mogaung was the first place in Burma to be liberated from the Japanese, and it was the last major Chindit campaign of the war. Two [[Victoria Cross]]es were awarded during the battle.<ref name=\"Griffin163\">{{Harvnb

column1: In 1943, Brigadier [[Orde Wingate]] led the Chindits behind Japanese lines for the first of their [[Long-range penetration]] operations with Operation ''Loincloth''. It resulted in little strategic success but it did prove that [[British Empire]] forces could fight on equal terms with the Japanese in the jungle. The following year General [[William Slim, 1st Viscount Slim
column2: William 'Bill' Slim]] leading the British [[Fourteenth Army (United Kingdom)
column3: Fourteenth Army]] were engaged in a desperate struggle against the Japanese army who had launched [[Operation U-Go]] - the invasion of [[British India]] beginning in March 1944.<ref name=\"Fay262\">{{Harvnb

column1: As a result of the Japanese invasion a second Chindit expedition was launched; Operation ''Thursday'' was much larger than the previous years' with six brigades. The aim was to harass the Japanese rear and supply lines as well as to relieve pressure on American General [[Joseph Stilwell
column2: Vinegar 'Joe' Stilwell]]'s joint Chinese and US forces moving south into Northern Burma who were intending to take the strategic town of [[Myitkyina]]. The early operations of the Chindits were marred by the death of Wingate in an air crash. They then went under the command of Major General [[Walter Lentaigne]] but were eventually placed under the command of the [[Anglophobia
column6: p=361}}</ref> Once the operation was underway in March, 77 Brigade having held off superior Japanese forces for two months from their stronghold of ''White City''.

column1: In late May they were ordered north by Stilwell to the area of Mogaung to take the pressure off his Chinese forces as they were struggling in [[Siege of Myitkyina
column2: besieging Myitkyina]]. Capturing Mogaung meant that the Japanese lifeline northward would be cut and Myitkyina would inevitably fall. At the end of May, Fourteenth Army intelligence, backed by hazardous patrols from 77 Brigade, found that the Japanese had reinforced the defenders of Mogaung with four battalions from Lieutenant-General Hisashi Takeda's [[53rd Division (Imperial Japanese Army)
column3: 53rd Division]] to  just under 4,000 troops.<ref name=\"Allen369\">{{Harvnb
column6: p=369}}</ref> The 77th brigade consisted of four battalions; the [[Lancashire Fusiliers]], [[King's Regiment]], [[South Staffordshire Regiment
column7: South Staffordshire's]] and [[6th Queen Elizabeth's Own Gurkha Rifles]]s. Accompanying the brigade were [[Royal Air Force
column8: RAF]] liaison officers who would need high ground for radio contact from which to bring in close air support.<ref name=\"Diamond74\">{{Harvnb

column1: Getting to Mogaung would be difficult for the brigade however. There was no way of flying in and to the North of the town was the fast flowing Mogaung River and to the West diverging off was the Wetthauk Chaung river. The country to the East and South were interspersed by lakes, marshes with the only access being a two mile long Pinhmi road on a causeway. The British would have to use this in order to get there and would come up against villages on the outskirts that had been heavily fortified - with bunkers being constructed under the buildings.<ref name=\"Towill113\">{{Harvnb

On May 30 the brigade set off; the plan was to advance 160 miles to the town using the Pinhmi road as an axis. Their first priority was for the  need for an area for a small landing strip for evacuating the sick and wounded as well as an area for supplies to be dropped. Calvert had hoped to reach and even capture Mogaung by 5 June.<ref name=\"GibbsRyan141\">{{cite book
column6: title=Historical Record of the 6th Gurkha Rifles, Volume 2

column1: [[File:Ledo and Sodiya, India- Myitkyina, Myanmar- Batang (Ba), Litang, Gyaltang, Kham, Tibet- Burma Road terminus at Kunming, China 1945 map detail, from- Allied Third Burma Campaign Apri 1-May 1945 (cropped).jpg
column3: Location of Mogaung in Northern Burma]]

column1: The march was difficult - thick jungle intersected by deep ravines and the occasional sporadic firefight with the Japanese. Nevertheless on 2 June the South Staffordshires and the Gurkhas captured the village of [[Lakum]] after a fierce encounter with the Japanese. The village was a low laying hill overlooking the plain two miles south west of Mogaung. On the following day, another series of bitter encounters forced the Japanese off the surrounding hills - the Gurkhas seized a hamlet, later dubbed 'Gurkha Village', after wiping out the forty strong garrison there. They captured intact a large [[ammunition dump]], fifteen lorries and a camouflaged hospital full of medical supplies, as well as many sick Japanese soldiers. Many of these tried to escape without success and many more committed suicide.<ref name=\"Calvert230\">{{Harvnb

Calvert had his headquarters operational just south of Lakum and a small airstrip was hastily laid from which supplies were arranged to be flown in and dropped by [[C-47]]'s. The wounded and sick could be flown out by using [[Stinson L-5 Sentinel
column2: Sentinal]] aircraft and even the new [[Sikorsky R-4]] helicopters.<ref name=\"M,M,M\">{{cite book
column9: title=A History of the 4th Prince of Wales's Own Gurkha Rifles, 1857-1948, Volume 3
column13: url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=q8MDAAAAMAAJ&q=}}</ref> An RAF liaison officers set up a position from which to use air support from the US [[1st Special Operations Wing
column14: 1st Air Commando Group]] for further combat sorties in taking Mogaung. Calvert also built up a store of medical, food and military supplies before any major attack went in. At the same time local [[Kachin people
column15: Kachin]] groups led by former [[Burma Rifles]] officers who had established control of the area joined Calvert's men to provide vital intelligence on Japanese movements.<ref name=\"Rooney97\">{{Harvnb
column18: pp=97-99}}</ref> The following day two platoons of the Lancashire fusiliers captured a vital point on the Mogaung river known as the Tapaw Ferry that would prove useful if the Chindits needed an escape route.<ref name=\"Kirby408\">{{cite book
column21: title=The War Against Japan: The decisive battles Volume 3 of The War Against Japan

column1: The villages of Mahaung, Natgyigon and the Pinhmi bridge on the outskirts of Mogaung were key positions in its defence; once these had fallen the Japanese hold on the town would become untenable. In Mogaung itself the courthouse and railway station were potential areas for heavy resistance as they were the two main all brick buildings. Over the next few days the brigade got supplied - they were delivered [[PIAT]] anti tank weapons as well as [[Flamethrower, Portable, No 2
column4: 4.2 inch]] mortars with thousands of rounds as the only means of heavy fire support. Japanese artillery was causing casualties but Calvert was eventually able to call in [[P-51 Mustang]]s of 1st Air Commando in an attempt to silence the Japanese positions.<ref name=\"Smith277\">{{Harvnb

column1: The attack on the Pinhmi to Mogaung road where the vital Pinhmi bridge crossed the Wetthauk Chaung river began on 7 June. As they advanced closer to Mogaung the Staffordshires found and destroyed a Japanese ammunition dump and the Lancashire Fusiliers later captured the village of Pinhmi. An attempt on the bridge the following day however failed as the Lancashires were repelled from concealed Japanese positions which ranged along a fifteen foot high embankment incurring heavy casualties.<ref name=\"Kirby408\"/> Nevertheless a reconnaissance patrol found a ford further down the river and from this the Gurkhas and the Staffordshires attacked and secured the village of Mahaung. In addition they also secured the village of Ywathitgale taking out a Japanese administrative headquarters, and reached the Pinhmi–Mogaung road outflanking a number of Japanese positions.<ref name=\"Rooney97\">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=97-99}}</ref> They then launched a number of counterattacks but were driven off. On 10 June the Gurkha's attempted to take the bridge again; the first attempt ended in failure but the second in a wide flanking move succeeded in taking the bridge. Among them was Captain [[Michael Allmand]]'s heroic feat in ensuring the capture of the bridge. The attacks cost nearly 130 casualties but Calvert's brigade was securely established along the axis of the Pinhmi-Mogaung road.<ref name=\"Diamond70\">{{Harvnb

column1: The [[monsoon]] then broke later that day and conditions were tough for the men of 77 Brigade; [[malaria]], [[trench foot]] and [[typhus]] were soon rife.<ref name=\"Allen371\">{{Harvnb
column4: p=371}}</ref> Calvert learnt that two more Japanese battalions arrived to reinforce Mogaung essentially replacing casualties, and seeing the difficulty he then sent a messenger to Stilwell to alert him to the situation; but was not received with any sympathy. Stilwell eventually sent the 1/114th Chinese Infantry Regiment from the 38th Division to support the Chindits.<ref name=\"Bidwell270\">{{Harvnb
column7: pp=270-71}}</ref> Calvert assessed the situation on June 12; many battalions were reduced to a company which meant the brigade total consisted of no more than 750 fit men. Calvert was concerned with the number of wounded and the sick having to endure the poor conditions - [[Defensive fighting position
column8: slit trenches]] were impossible due to the wet conditions; men would have to lay face down in the mud if they were under shell fire. Many of the wounded however were determined to stay and fight rather than be flown out.<ref name=\"Rooney100\">{{Harvnb

column1: Over the next few days conditions began to improve many of the wounded were flown out and supplies were brought in once more. On June 15 Calvert continued his attacks, fighting to secure a ridge closer to the town. The Court House was taken the next day, and the area extending to the Mogaung River and up to the outskirts of Natgyigon was cleared.<ref name=\"Kirby408\"/> Japanese mortar fire from the village of Naungkaiktaw was causing some grief upon the Chindits. At dawn on June 18 air attacks and a heavy mortar bombardment over the next few days followed by an assault by the Lancashire Fusiliers and the King's attacked using flamethrowers.<ref name=\"Diamond80\">{{Harvnb
column4: p=80}}</ref> At the cost of some fifty casualties (some from friendly fire) they succeeded and drove around a hundred Japanese out of the village in addition to killing some seventy of them. Whilst consolidating their position in the village a Japanese patrol was ambushed and taken out; they had not realised the village had been in British hands.<ref name=\"Rooney100\"/>

column1: Around the same time Chinese troops began to arrive; Gurkhas made contact with them West of Lakum. Mogaung was then surrounded, with the Chinese in the South which totalled nearly three battalions. Crucially they had [[Bofors 75 mm mountain gun
column2: 75mm mountain guns]] which were established at Pinhmi, and they were able pound Japanese positions.<ref name=\"McLynn352\">{{Harvnb

column4: Gurkha Captain Michael Allmand who won the VC during the Battle of Mogaung]]

column1: Calvert planned his next attack for 23 June towards Natyigon, a key position and the last outer bastion of Mogaung. At first light on that day the final assault was launched; every available fit man was called up; cooks, orderlies and even Headquarters personnel. The Chinese attacked towards the railway station along the railway embankment which was effectively a last line of defence. Despite a heavy bombardment the attack failed and the Chinese were held back with intense Japanese machine gun fire. The Chindits had no choice but to halt along this line for the remainder of the day.<ref name=\"Bidwell270\"/>

Earlier reconnaissance had pin-pointed the 'Red House', a large bricked building. The following day after a heavy bombardment from the Chinese guns and British mortars as well as air attacks the British attacked from the North of the station. Once once more fighting was intense, the Japanese defending tenaciously despite the constant pounding. The building and surrounding positions were only taken after brutal fighting in which flamethrowers, grenades and PIATs were used.<ref name=\"GibbsRyan143\">Gibbs & Ryan pp. 143-44</ref> One of the men involved was Rifleman [[Tulbahadur Pun]]; his single-handed gallantry as part of the Gurkhas attack on the 'Red House' earned him a nomination for the Victoria Cross. The other nomination fell to Michael Allmand who attacked a machine-gun position holding up his remaining company. He Knocked out the position with grenades but was mortally wounded in the process. The Chinese provided some fire support but did not take part in this attack, instead protecting the flanks and cutting off any Japanese escape attempt. The assault by the Gurkhas totally unbalanced the Japanese and Takeda had no other choice to withdraw or risk his battalions being destroyed.<ref name=\"Corrigan\">{{Harvnb

The final attack was on the railway station on June 25 - the Chinese attack from the South was postponed but the Lancashires and the South Staffordshires went in anyway and after more heavy fighting finally took the battered remains and met up with the Chinese.<ref name=\"Lunt39\">{{Harvnb
column4: p=39}}</ref> With the British having major foothold in the town, the Japanese launched a number of counter attacks that night but they were beaten off. The following morning the Chindit and Chinese patrols found positions outside the town abandoned.<ref name=\"Smith277\"/> Any Japanese that escaped did so by using [[Drum (container)
column5: oil drums]] in the hope they would make it downriver to Myitkyina. Many however were shot up by patrolling Chindits.<ref name=\"Bidwell273\">{{Harvnb

column1: With the battle largely over the Chindits consolidated their position in Mogaung but they were physically and mentally exhausted. The brigade at the end of the battle only had less than 550 men left of fighting strength. The Lancashire Fusiliers, King's Regiment and South Staffordshire's between them could only muster 300 between them and the 3/6th Gurkhas had 230 left fit.<ref name=\"Calvert180\">{{Harvnb

Once Mogaung had been captured the Gurkha's garrisoned the town preparing for further counterattacks from across the river but none was forthcoming; the Japanese had left the area completely.<ref name=\"McLynn352\"/> Whilst in Mogaung, the Gurkha's took the opportunity to hold a small ceremonial parade and hoisted the Union Jack on a large [[pagoda]], the most prominent building left standing. The Chindits remained in the area until July 5 and then withdrew to their base area at Pinhmi. They then had to march a further fifty miles to be flown back to India before leaving Mogaung in the hands of the Chinese.<ref name=\"Calvert180\"/>

The capture of Mogaung was the first place in Burma to be liberated from the Japanese, and it was the last major Chindit campaign of the war.<ref name=\"Griffin163\"/> The Japanese had lost heavily with nearly 1,600 casualties most of whom were dead and and an unknown number of sick that evacuated.<ref name=\"Allen374\"/> The cost of taking Mogaung had been high - Calvert had lost 47 officers and 729 other ranks killed or wounded; which equated to around fifty percent casualties. Stilwell had used the Chindits in an unsuitable role of classic infantry, without the support of artillery and armour. He announced via the [[British Broadcasting Corporation
column2: BBC]] that Chinese troops of his [[Northern Combat Area Command]] had captured Mogaung but without referencing the British. The Chindits were outraged, and Calvert famously signalled to Stilwell's headquarters 'Chinese reported taking Mogaung. My Brigade now taking umbrage.' Stillwell's son who was the intelligence officer announced that 'Umbrage was so small that I can't find it on the map'.<ref name=\"Rooney105\">{{Harvnb

column1: Fearing that they would then be ordered to join the siege of Myitkyina, Calvert shut down his radios and withdrew to [[Kamaing]], where Stilwell had his headquarters. A court-martial was likely until Stilwell and Calvert met in person, and the former finally appreciated the conditions under which the Chindits had been operating.<ref name=\"Allen374\"/> The siege of Myitkyina had already proved a thorn in Stilwell's side after a major Chinese assault had been repelled with heavy losses. The British capture of Mogaung did relieve pressure on Stilwell's troops besieging the town; the Japanese quit Myitkyina on 3 August.<ref name=\"MM\">{{cite book
column3: title=Merrill's Marauders, February - May 1944 American forces in action series Volume 100, Issue 4
column5: publisher=Printing Office Center of Military History

column1: Two Victoria Crosses were awarded during the battle - Michael Allmand received his [[Posthumous award
column2: posthumously]], while Tul Bahadur Pun received his in November.<ref name=\"Griffin163\"/> In addition members of the Sixth Gurkhas also received two [[Distinguished Service Order

column13: url-status=dead}}</ref> The South Staffordshires, Kings and Lancashire fusiliers also received many awards. Calvert was awarded the DSO and [[Medal bar
column14: Bar]] and the American Silver Star for the capture of Mogaung.<ref name=\"Brown\">{{Harvnb
column17: p=32}}</ref> He was evacuated to Britain on medical grounds following an accidental injury in September 1944. In March 1945 he was appointed to command the [[Special Air Service]] Brigade taking command of various operations in the [[Western Allied invasion of Germany]] devising [[Operation Amherst
column18: Operation ''Amherst'']]. He held this appointment until the brigade disbanded in October 1945.<ref name=\"Ladd99\">{{Harvnb

column4: title=The Chindit War: Stilwell, Wingate, and the Campaign in Burma, 1944
title=Burma Road 1943–44: Stilwell's assault on Myitkyina
title=The Second World War: A Military History

column5: title=The Forgotten Army: India's Armed Struggle for Independence, 1942–1945.

column4: title=Jai Sixth!: 6th Queen Elizabeth's own Gurkha Rifles 1817–1994
title=The Burma Campaign: Disaster into Triumph 1942-45
title=Mad Mike: Biography of Brigadier Michael Calvert

column1: [[Category:World War II operations and battles of the Southeast Asia Theatre]]
[[Category:Military history of Burma during World War II]]
[[Category:Battles of World War II involving Japan]]
[[Category:Land battles of World War II involving the United Kingdom]]

column2: partof      = the [[Burma Campaign]] of the [[World War II
caption     = Brigadier Mike Calvert (left) gives orders to Lieutenant-Colonel Shaw, with (right) Major James Lumley after the capture of Mogaung.

column1: The '''Battle of Mogaung''' was a series of engagements that was fought in the [[Burma Campaign]] of [[World War II]] between 6 to 26 June 1944 at the Burmese town of Mogaung. In brutal fighting, the [[77th Indian Infantry Brigade
column3: Michael Calvert]], later assisted by [[Chinese Expeditionary Force
column4: Chinese forces]] of Generalissimo [[Chiang Kai-shek]], fought-for and captured the town from the [[Japanese occupation of Burma

column1: The battle was part of a major [[Chindit]] campaign called [[Chindits#Operation Thursday
column2: Operation ''Thursday'']] which later amalgamated with the [[Siege of Myitkyina]] by Chinese and US forces led by [[Joseph Stilwell]] who was in overall command of the Chindits. The capture of Mogaung was the first place in Burma to be liberated from the Japanese, and it was the last major Chindit campaign of the war. Two [[Victoria Cross]]es were awarded during the battle.<ref name=\"Griffin163\">{{Harvnb

column1: In 1943, Brigadier [[Orde Wingate]] led the Chindits behind Japanese lines for the first of their [[Long-range penetration]] operations with Operation ''Loincloth''. It resulted in little strategic success but it did prove that [[British Empire]] forces could fight on equal terms with the Japanese in the jungle. The following year General [[William Slim, 1st Viscount Slim
column2: William 'Bill' Slim]] leading the British [[Fourteenth Army (United Kingdom)
column3: Fourteenth Army]] were engaged in a desperate struggle against the Japanese army who had launched [[Operation U-Go]] - the invasion of [[British India]] beginning in March 1944.<ref name=\"Fay262\">{{Harvnb

column1: As a result of the Japanese invasion a second Chindit expedition was launched; Operation ''Thursday'' was much larger than the previous years' with six brigades. The aim was to harass the Japanese rear and supply lines as well as to relieve pressure on American General [[Joseph Stilwell
column2: Vinegar 'Joe' Stilwell]]'s joint Chinese and US forces moving south into Northern Burma who were intending to take the strategic town of [[Myitkyina]]. The early operations of the Chindits were marred by the death of Wingate in an air crash. They then went under the command of Major General [[Walter Lentaigne]] but were eventually placed under the command of the [[Anglophobia
column6: p=361}}</ref> Once the operation was underway in March, 77 Brigade having held off superior Japanese forces for two months from their stronghold of ''White City''.

column1: In late May they were ordered north by Stilwell to the area of Mogaung to take the pressure off his Chinese forces as they were struggling in [[Siege of Myitkyina
column2: besieging Myitkyina]]. Capturing Mogaung meant that the Japanese lifeline northward would be cut and Myitkyina would inevitably fall. At the end of May, Fourteenth Army intelligence, backed by hazardous patrols from 77 Brigade, found that the Japanese had reinforced the defenders of Mogaung with four battalions from Lieutenant-General Hisashi Takeda's [[53rd Division (Imperial Japanese Army)
column3: 53rd Division]] to  just under 4,000 troops.<ref name=\"Allen369\">{{Harvnb
column6: p=369}}</ref> The 77th brigade consisted of four battalions; the [[Lancashire Fusiliers]], [[King's Regiment]], [[South Staffordshire Regiment
column7: South Staffordshire's]] and [[6th Queen Elizabeth's Own Gurkha Rifles]]s. Accompanying the brigade were [[Royal Air Force
column8: RAF]] liaison officers who would need high ground for radio contact from which to bring in close air support.<ref name=\"Diamond74\">{{Harvnb

column1: Getting to Mogaung would be difficult for the brigade however. There was no way of flying in and to the North of the town was the fast flowing Mogaung River and to the West diverging off was the Wetthauk Chaung river. The country to the East and South were interspersed by lakes, marshes with the only access being a two mile long Pinhmi road on a causeway. The British would have to use this in order to get there and would come up against villages on the outskirts that had been heavily fortified - with bunkers being constructed under the buildings.<ref name=\"Towill113\">{{Harvnb

On May 30 the brigade set off; the plan was to advance 160 miles to the town using the Pinhmi road as an axis. Their first priority was for the  need for an area for a small landing strip for evacuating the sick and wounded as well as an area for supplies to be dropped. Calvert had hoped to reach and even capture Mogaung by 5 June.<ref name=\"GibbsRyan141\">{{cite book
column6: title=Historical Record of the 6th Gurkha Rifles, Volume 2

column1: [[File:Ledo and Sodiya, India- Myitkyina, Myanmar- Batang (Ba), Litang, Gyaltang, Kham, Tibet- Burma Road terminus at Kunming, China 1945 map detail, from- Allied Third Burma Campaign Apri 1-May 1945 (cropped).jpg
column3: Location of Mogaung in Northern Burma]]

column1: The march was difficult - thick jungle intersected by deep ravines and the occasional sporadic firefight with the Japanese. Nevertheless on 2 June the South Staffordshires and the Gurkhas captured the village of [[Lakum]] after a fierce encounter with the Japanese. The village was a low laying hill overlooking the plain two miles south west of Mogaung. On the following day, another series of bitter encounters forced the Japanese off the surrounding hills - the Gurkhas seized a hamlet, later dubbed 'Gurkha Village', after wiping out the forty strong garrison there. They captured intact a large [[ammunition dump]], fifteen lorries and a camouflaged hospital full of medical supplies, as well as many sick Japanese soldiers. Many of these tried to escape without success and many more committed suicide.<ref name=\"Calvert230\">{{Harvnb

Calvert had his headquarters operational just south of Lakum and a small airstrip was hastily laid from which supplies were arranged to be flown in and dropped by [[C-47]]'s. The wounded and sick could be flown out by using [[Stinson L-5 Sentinel
column2: Sentinal]] aircraft and even the new [[Sikorsky R-4]] helicopters.<ref name=\"M,M,M\">{{cite book
column9: title=A History of the 4th Prince of Wales's Own Gurkha Rifles, 1857-1948, Volume 3
column13: url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=q8MDAAAAMAAJ&q=}}</ref> An RAF liaison officers set up a position from which to use air support from the US [[1st Special Operations Wing
column14: 1st Air Commando Group]] for further combat sorties in taking Mogaung. Calvert also built up a store of medical, food and military supplies before any major attack went in. At the same time local [[Kachin people
column15: Kachin]] groups led by former [[Burma Rifles]] officers who had established control of the area joined Calvert's men to provide vital intelligence on Japanese movements.<ref name=\"Rooney97\">{{Harvnb
column18: pp=97-99}}</ref> The following day two platoons of the Lancashire fusiliers captured a vital point on the Mogaung river known as the Tapaw Ferry that would prove useful if the Chindits needed an escape route.<ref name=\"Kirby408\">{{cite book
column21: title=The War Against Japan: The decisive battles Volume 3 of The War Against Japan

column13: url-status=dead}}</ref> The South Staffordshires, Kings and Lancashire fusiliers also received many awards. Calvert was awarded the DSO and [[Medal bar
column14: Bar]] and the American Silver Star for the capture of Mogaung.<ref name=\"Brown\">{{Harvnb
column17: p=32}}</ref> He was evacuated to Britain on medical grounds following an accidental injury in September 1944. In March 1945 he was appointed to command the [[Special Air Service]] Brigade taking command of various operations in the [[Western Allied invasion of Germany]] devising [[Operation Amherst
column18: Operation ''Amherst'']]. He held this appointment until the brigade disbanded in October 1945.<ref name=\"Ladd99\">{{Harvnb
